A critical vulnerability in MikroTik RouterOS exposes over half a million devices to potential hacking.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 361/66 (IT) on Thursday, July 27, 2023, reported a severe privilege escalation issue affecting MikroTik RouterOS.  Attackers can remotely exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code and take complete control of vulnerable devices.  A report released Tuesday revealed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-30799 (CVSS score: 9.1), affects approximately 500,000 RouterOS systems, making them susceptible to attacks via the web or Winbox interface.  VulnCheck notes that CVE-2023-30799 was initially disclosed by Margin Research as an exploit called FOISted (without a CVE identifier).  This vulnerability in Mikrotik routers was exploited to incorporate devices into denial-of-service (DDoS) botnets. Users are strongly advised to patch the vulnerability by updating to the latest version (6.49.8 or 7.x) as soon as possible.  Mitigation recommendations include removing the MikroTik administrative interface from the internet, blocking administrator login IP addresses, disabling Winbox and the web interface, and configuring SSH to use public/private keys and disable passwords. Process Injection: Proc Memory is techniques, 

Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via the /proc filesystem in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Proc memory injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. 
Proc memory injection involves enumerating the memory of a process via the /proc filesystem (
) then crafting a return-oriented programming (ROP) payload with available gadgets/instructions. Each running process has its own directory, which includes memory mappings. Proc memory injection is commonly performed by overwriting the target processes’ stack using memory mappings provided by the /proc filesystem. This information can be used to enumerate offsets (including the stack) and gadgets (or instructions within the program that can be used to build a malicious payload) otherwise hidden by process memory protections such as address space layout randomization (ASLR). Once enumerated, the target processes’ memory map within 
 can be overwritten using dd.
 
Other techniques such as 
 may be used to populate a target process with more available gadgets. Similar to 
, proc memory injection may target child processes (such as a backgrounded copy of sleep).
 
Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via proc memory injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process. 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/009/

Server Software Component: SQL Stored Procedures is techniques, 

Adversaries may abuse SQL stored procedures to establish persistent access to systems. SQL Stored Procedures are code that can be saved and reused so that database users do not waste time rewriting frequently used SQL queries. Stored procedures can be invoked via SQL statements to the database using the procedure name or via defined events (e.g. when a SQL server application is started/restarted).
Adversaries may craft malicious stored procedures that can provide a persistence mechanism in SQL database servers.
 To execute operating system commands through SQL syntax the adversary may have to enable additional functionality, such as xp_cmdshell for MSSQL Server.
 
Microsoft SQL Server can enable common language runtime (CLR) integration. With CLR integration enabled, application developers can write stored procedures using any .NET framework language (e.g. VB .NET, C#, etc.).
 Adversaries may craft or modify CLR assemblies that are linked to stored procedures since these CLR assemblies can be made to execute arbitrary commands.
 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1505/001/

Subvert Trust Controls: Code Signing Policy Modification is techniques, 

Adversaries may modify code signing policies to enable execution of unsigned or self-signed code. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a program from a developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with. Security controls can include enforcement mechanisms to ensure that only valid, signed code can be run on an operating system. 
Some of these security controls may be enabled by default, such as Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) on Windows or System Integrity Protection (SIP) on macOS.
 Other such controls may be disabled by default but are configurable through application controls, such as only allowing signed Dynamic-Link Libraries (DLLs) to execute on a system. Since it can be useful for developers to modify default signature enforcement policies during the development and testing of applications, disabling of these features may be possible with elevated permissions.
Adversaries may modify code signing policies in a number of ways, including through use of command-line or GUI utilities, 
, rebooting the computer in a debug/recovery mode, or by altering the value of variables in kernel memory.
 Examples of commands that can modify the code signing policy of a system include 
 on Windows and 
 on macOS.
 Depending on the implementation, successful modification of a signing policy may require reboot of the compromised system. Additionally, some implementations can introduce visible artifacts for the user (ex: a watermark in the corner of the screen stating the system is in Test Mode). Adversaries may attempt to remove such artifacts.
To gain access to kernel memory to modify variables related to signature checks, such as modifying 
 to disable Driver Signature Enforcement, adversaries may conduct 
 using a signed, but vulnerable driver.

Event Triggered Execution is techniques, 

Adversaries may establish persistence using system mechanisms that trigger execution based on specific events. Mobile operating systems have means to subscribe to events such as receiving an SMS message, device boot completion, or other device activities. 
Adversaries may abuse these mechanisms as a means of maintaining persistent access to a victim via automatically and repeatedly executing malicious code. After gaining access to a victim’s system, adversaries may create or modify event triggers to point to malicious content that will be executed whenever the event trigger is invoked. 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1624

Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols is techniques, 

Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with web protocols traffic to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to remote mobile devices, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the mobile client and server. 
Web protocols such as HTTP and HTTPS are used for web traffic as well as well as notification services native to mobile messaging services such as Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) and newly, Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM), (GCM/FCM: two-way communication) and Apple Push Notification Service (APNS; one-way server-to-device).  Such notification services leverage HTTP/S via the respective API and are commonly abused on Android and iOS respectively in order blend in with routine device traffic making it difficult for enterprises to inspect. 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1437/001/

Alert - Detection Report of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand

The TTC-CERT has examined several suspicious files received from a Thai security agency and found that all files are part of a cyberattack specifically targeting Thailand. The attack utilizes sophisticated malware to achieve cyber espionage objectives. The TTC-CERT has named this campaign BangkokShell.

Overall, the BangkokShell campaign leverages open-source projects to develop attack tools and employs various anti-detection measures such as Dynamic API Resolution, Indirect Calls, stackstrings, and multiple encryption types. The BangkokShell attack process begins with DLL Side-loading to load obfuscated shellcode into the process memory before deobfuscating it. It then uses Reflective Code Loading to load and execute the payload, a Remote Access Trojan (RAT), without leaving any traces on the filesystem.  TTC-CERT refers to this payload as RahadRAT. Analysis reveals interesting self-protection mechanisms, including password authentication support and the use of the CRC-16/XMODEM algorithm to verify data exchanged between the malware and the Command and Control (C2) server.  It supports 14 C2 commands designed to control and collect data from the target computer before obfuscating it with the RC4 (Rivest Cipher 4) algorithm and sending it to the C2.
 URL: https://drive.google.com/file/d/14OdsocsRVK6osG3TLxyGSB0fJZaaS2fK/view

LockBit ransomware group claims to have hacked Fairfield Memorial Hospital in the US.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 239/67 (IT) Friday, July 5, 2024. The LockBit ransomware group has claimed responsibility for hacking the systems of Fairfield Memorial Hospital in Illinois, USA.  This incident is another example of US healthcare facilities experiencing cybersecurity breaches. Fairfield Memorial Hospital is located in Fairfield, Illinois, has 25 emergency beds, and more than 400 staff members. The hospital provides a variety of medical services, including emergency services, general surgery, intensive care unit (ICU), and orthopedics.  The LockBit group claims to have stolen data from the hospital's healthcare infrastructure and added it to the group's website. The stolen data will be released on July 17, 2024.  In addition, researchers from Hack Manack reported that the ransomware group also claimed responsibility for hacking Merryman House and the Florida Department of Health, attacks that put people's lives at risk. This week, Wayne Memorial Hospital in Pennsylvania also fell victim to a cyberattack by the Monti group.  And in February, Lurie Children's Hospital, one of the leading children's hospitals in the United States, experienced a cyberattack that impacted operations.  Currently, the US healthcare infrastructure continues to face increasing risks from cyberattacks. Chinese-linked hackers have attempted to compromise phones used by Donald Trump and JD Vance.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 379/67 (IT) reported on Monday, October 28, 2024, citing the New York Times, that a group of hackers linked to China attempted to infiltrate the phones used by former President Donald Trump and Senator JD Vance, a potential vice-presidential candidate in the next US presidential election.  The attacks are part of a cyber espionage campaign aimed at gathering information about US leaders. US intelligence agencies are investigating what communications the hackers may have intercepted.  Unnamed sources indicated the hacking group's infiltration was sophisticated, successfully breaching telecommunications systems. The information obtained from Trump and Vance's phones is considered a valuable source of intelligence for foreign entities, particularly in the lead-up to the presidential election. Sources close to the matter informed CNN that the APT group "Salt Typhoon" also targeted individuals within the Harris-Walz campaign team and senior Biden administration officials.  The group also demonstrated advanced skills in penetrating communications systems and internet networks of major companies like AT&T, Verizon, and Lume. Once US security agencies identified the attacks, agencies like the FBI and CISA immediately alerted and provided technical assistance to the affected telecommunications companies, and shared information with other companies to prevent future attacks. The House and Senate Intelligence Committees have been briefed on the intrusions and are closely monitoring the situation.  The Chinese government continues to deny accusations of involvement in the cyberattacks. American Water faces cyberattack, temporarily shuts down some systems. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 358/67 (IT) Thursday, October 10, 2024. American Water, the largest water and wastewater utility company in the U.S., has decided to temporarily shut down some of its systems after discovering a cyberattack on October 2, 2024. Although this attack did not affect water and wastewater operations, the company temporarily shut down its MyWater portal service, and customer service centers will have limited functionality. American Water, which provides water and wastewater services to approximately 14 million customers in 14 U.S. states, confirmed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it has followed security protocols by engaging external security experts and immediately notifying law enforcement officials to investigate and control the situation.  The company stated that the shutdown of the MyWater portal aims to protect customer data, promising that there will be no late fees or service shutdowns at this time. It also confirmed that drinking water remains safe for consumption. This incident occurs amid a wave of cyberattacks targeting companies in the U.S. national infrastructure sector, particularly water and wastewater systems, which are key targets for hackers. Adversaries may perform data destruction over the course of an operation. The adversary may drop or create malware, tools, or other non-native files on a target system to accomplish this, potentially leaving behind traces of malicious activities. Testing cooperation of EU CSIRTs Network during large-scale cyber-attacks
On 15 May 2019, the EU Agency for Cybersecurity  organised and participated in CyberSOPEx2019, the second dedicated cooperation exercise of the EU CSIRTs Network (CNW).

The role of  was twofold. On the one hand, the CSIRT Relations team actively participated as the secretariat of CNW, as defined by the NIS Directive. In this regard,  provides overall support to CNW and manages tools for cooperation among all members. On the other hand, ’s exercise team, which also organises the pan-European ‘Cyber Europe’ exercise, organised the exercise, including the definition of the scenario and injects, and controlled the execution.
CSIRT teams from 27 countries, CERT-EU and  played a scenario where cyber-attacks were performed over critical infrastructures before and during European elections. Several operators of essential services across different Member States were the ‘target’ of the attacks, and some incidents tried to diminish trust in the electoral process. Over 50 incident-handling experts from the EU Member States participated in this exercise.
CyberSOPex2019 proved once more how fundamental in developing confidence and trust among Member States the CNW is, promoting swift and effective operational cooperation.
The CyberSOPEx type of exercise is an important part of ’s continuous efforts to improve the large-scale incident response collaboration of the CSIRTs Network members, by focusing on training participants on situational awareness, information sharing, understanding roles and procedures, and utilising CSIRTs Network-related tools just like in a real life situation.
For more info on the CSIRTs Network, visit
www.csirtsnetwork.eu
For more information on the ’s exercises contact:
exercises@.europa.eu URL: https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/testing-cooperation-of-eu-csirts-network-during-large-scale-cyber-attacks

Web Service: Dead Drop Resolver is techniques, 

Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service to host information that points to additional command and control (C2) infrastructure. Adversaries may post content, known as a dead drop resolver, on Web services with embedded (and often obfuscated/encoded) domains or IP addresses. Once infected, victims will reach out to and be redirected by these resolvers. 
Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection. 
Use of a dead drop resolver may also protect back-end C2 infrastructure from discovery through malware binary analysis, or enable operational resiliency (since this infrastructure may be dynamically changed). 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1481/001/

LiteSpeed plugin vulnerability in WordPress puts over 5 million websites at risk.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 81/67 (IT) on Thursday, February 29, 2024, disclosed a security vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin in WordPress that could allow unauthorized users to escalate their privileges. The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-40000, was patched in October 2023 in version 5.7.0.1. The LiteSpeed Cache plugin has been installed over 5 million times, with the latest version, 6.1, released on February 5, 2024. However, WordPress security authorities say CVE-2023-40000 resulted from a lack of user input sanitization and output escaping.  The vulnerability is rooted in a function called update_cdn_status() and is reproducible in default installations.  "Because the XSS payload is placed as an admin notice, and admin notices can be displayed on wp-admin endpoints, this vulnerability can easily be exploited by users with access to the wp-admin area." This allows authenticated attackers with contributor-level privileges and above to inject arbitrary web scripts into web pages that will execute whenever a user accesses the injected page. GitLab releases fix for Critical vulnerability that can bypass SAML authentication.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 333/67 (IT) Friday, September 20, 2024. GitLab has released an update to address a Critical vulnerability affecting the Community Edition (CE) and Enterprise Edition (EE). This is a SAML authentication bypass, tracked as CVE-2024-45409, with a CVSS score of 10. The vulnerability stems from an issue in GitLab's OmniAuth-SAML and Ruby-SAML libraries, which are used to manage SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication.  This issue arises when the SAML response sent by the Identity Provider (IdP) to GitLab is misconfigured or modified. This allows attackers to craft malicious SAML responses to trick GitLab into recognizing the attacker as an authenticated user, bypassing SAML authentication and gaining access to the GitLab instance.  The vulnerability affects GitLab versions 17.3.3, 17.2.7, 17.1.8, 17.0.8, and 16.11.10. GitLab has updated OmniAuth SAML to version 2.2.1 and Ruby-SAML to version 1.17.0 and recommends users update to the latest versions as soon as possible. For those who cannot update immediately, GitLab recommends enabling two-factor authentication (2FA) for all accounts and setting SAML 2FA bypass to "Disallow".  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/09/20/gitlab-%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%89%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%82%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b0%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%9a-cri/

met the new members of its Permanent Stakeholders Group today in Athens
The first meeting of the recently elected Permanent Stakeholders’ Group (PSG) was held in Athens on 29 and 30 November 2017, during which topics of the Agency's forthcoming work programmes were discussed.

The current PSG consisting of 33 top IT-security experts, has been appointed following an open Call for Expression of Interest for Membership earlier this year. A new PSG is appointed every 2 ½ years, and the current group will serve from 2017-2020.
The group is composed of “nominated members” from three organizations namely Europol, BEREC and Art.29 Working Party and members appointed “ad personam”, a total of 33 members from all over Europe.
The PSG advises the Executive Director on the development of the Agency’s work programme, and on ensuring the communication with the relevant stakeholders on all related issues.

Adversaries may modify or add LSASS drivers to obtain persistence on compromised systems. The Windows security subsystem is a set of components that manage and enforce the security policy for a computer or domain. The Local Security Authority (LSA) is the main component responsible for local security policy and user authentication. The LSA includes multiple dynamic link libraries (DLLs) associated with various other security functions, all of which run in the context of the LSA Subsystem Service (LSASS) lsass.exe process.
Adversaries may target LSASS drivers to obtain persistence. By either replacing or adding illegitimate drivers (e.g., 
), an adversary can use LSA operations to continuously execute malicious payloads.

The European Union Agency for Cybersecurity hosted (virtually) the annual meeting for EU ISACs, where they exchanged views, and discussed challenges and solutions.

nd
Inter-EU ISACs meeting on the 10

The meeting allowed experts of the EU Information Sharing and Analysis Centres (ISACs) to build on trust, get to know new members coming from newly formed ISACs, review developments from last year’s in-person meeting and identify synergies to enhance collaboration between the centres. Pre-OS Boot: Bootkit is techniques, 

Adversaries may use bootkits to persist on systems. Bootkits reside at a layer below the operating system and may make it difficult to perform full remediation unless an organization suspects one was used and can act accordingly.
A bootkit is a malware variant that modifies the boot sectors of a hard drive, including the Master Boot Record (MBR) and Volume Boot Record (VBR). 
 The MBR is the section of disk that is first loaded after completing hardware initialization by the BIOS. It is the location of the boot loader. An adversary who has raw access to the boot drive may overwrite this area, diverting execution during startup from the normal boot loader to adversary code. 
The MBR passes control of the boot process to the VBR. Similar to the case of MBR, an adversary who has raw access to the boot drive may overwrite the VBR to divert execution during startup to adversary code.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/003/

SolarWinds patches multiple vulnerabilities in Serv-U and SolarWinds Platform.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 204/67 (IT) Monday, June 10, 2024. SolarWinds has released patches to address multiple high-severity vulnerabilities in Serv-U and SolarWinds Platform affecting Platform 2024.1 SR 1 and earlier versions. One of the fixed vulnerabilities, reported by a penetration tester working with NATO, is CVE-2024-28996 (CVSS score 7.5), which allowed users to query the SolarWinds database for information about the network. This vulnerability was discovered by Nils Putnins from the NATO Communications and Information Agency.  SolarWinds also addressed several other externally reported vulnerabilities, including CVE-2024-28999 (CVSS score 6.4) and CVE-2024-29004 (CVSS score 7.1), which are a race condition and an XSS bug, respectively, residing in the web console.  SolarWinds released version 2024.2 to address these vulnerabilities. It is currently unclear if these vulnerabilities have been exploited in the wild. and ISACA Workshop Addresses Cybersecurity Challenges
 and ISACA hosted a joint workshop in Berlin on Tuesday (11th June) to address cybersecurity challenges for national regulators, telecom operators, ISPs and auditors. More than 25 organizations from 15 countries attended the event, held in conjunction with ISACA’s World Congress:  INSIGHTS 2013.

Themed “Auditing Security Measures in the Electronic Communications Sector,” the workshop covered Article 13a of the European Union Framework Directive of Telecom Reform.
Commenting on the event, ’s Head of Secure Infrastructure and Services, Dr. Evangelos Ouzounis, said:  “ISACA is a key network of network and information security (NIS) experts with a global reach, and  is very pleased to share our learning and experience with this highly respected group. The areas that ISACA works on, particularly security audits, complement ’s technical perspectives, and in our joint workshop we were able to consider security issues from the perspectives of regulatory authorities, service providers and auditors. This wide-ranging activity is fully in tune with ’s approach. Events like the ISACA World Congress bring the key players together, working to make cyberspace secure.”

CISA adds Android Pixel, Microsoft Windows, Progress Telerik Report Server to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 215/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 18, 2024.  The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added three vulnerabilities – Android Pixel, Microsoft Windows, and Progress Telerik Report Server – to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. – CVE-2024-32896 is a privilege escalation vulnerability in Android's Pixel Firmware, which has been exploited as a zero-day. – CVE-2024-26169 is a privilege escalation vulnerability in Microsoft Windows Error Reporting Service, which can be exploited to gain SYSTEM privileges. – CVE-2024-4358 is an authentication bypass vulnerability in Telerik Report Server that unauthenticated attackers can exploit to access restricted functionality.  To mitigate the risk of these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date.  To prevent attacks and exploitation of these vulnerabilities, experts recommend that private sector organizations also review the catalog and address these vulnerabilities. CISA has mandated that government agencies remediate these vulnerabilities by July 4, 2024.   URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/06/18/cisa-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%b4%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a1-android-pixel-microsoft-windows-progress-telerik-report-server-%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%99-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-kev-%e0%b9%81/

Improper Neutralization of Data within XPath Expressions ('XPath Injection') # Description : 
The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XPath expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
The net effect is that the attacker will have control over the information selected from the XML database and may use that ability to control application flow, modify logic, retrieve unauthorized data, or bypass important checks (e.g. authentication).

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Implementation

Execution Guardrails is techniques, 

Adversaries may use execution guardrails to constrain execution or actions based on adversary supplied and environment specific conditions that are expected to be present on the target. Guardrails ensure that a payload only executes against an intended target and reduces collateral damage from an adversary’s campaign.
 Values an adversary can provide about a target system or environment to use as guardrails may include specific network share names, attached physical devices, files, joined Active Directory (AD) domains, and local/external IP addresses.
Guardrails can be used to prevent exposure of capabilities in environments that are not intended to be compromised or operated within. This use of guardrails is distinct from typical 
. While use of 
 may involve checking for known sandbox values and continuing with execution only if there is no match, the use of guardrails will involve checking for an expected target-specific value and only continuing with execution if there is such a match.
Adversaries may identify and block certain user-agents to evade defenses and narrow the scope of their attack to victims and platforms on which it will be most effective. A user-agent self-identifies data such as a user's software application, operating system, vendor, and version. Adversaries may check user-agents for operating system identification and then only serve malware for the exploitable software while ignoring all other operating systems.

Adversaries may maintain persistence through executing malicious content triggered using udev rules. Udev is the Linux kernel device manager that dynamically manages device nodes, handles access to pseudo-device files in the 
 directory, and responds to hardware events, such as when external devices like hard drives or keyboards are plugged in or removed. Udev uses rule files with 
 to specify the conditions a hardware event must meet and 
 to define the actions that should follow. Root permissions are required to create, modify, or delete rule files located in 
, 
, 
, 
, and 
. Rule priority is determined by both directory and by the digit prefix in the rule filename.
Adversaries may abuse the udev subsystem by adding or modifying rules in udev rule files to execute malicious content. For example, an adversary may configure a rule to execute their binary each time the pseudo-device file, such as 
, is accessed by an application. Although udev is limited to running short tasks and is restricted by systemd-udevd's sandbox (blocking network and filesystem access), attackers may use scripting commands under the action key 
 to detach and run the malicious content’s process in the background to bypass these controls.

ALPHV Ransomware group claims attack on circuit court
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 448/66 (IT) Thursday, October 12, 2023. The ALPHV (BlackCat) ransomware group claims responsibility for the attack that affected the systems of the court across Northwest Florida last week. The group obtained personal details such as social security numbers and CVs of employees, including judges, and threatened to release the stolen data online to force the court back into negotiations. The Circuit Court revealed last week that it was investigating a cyberattack that disrupted operations on the morning of Monday, October 2nd. This incident will affect court operations in Escambia, Okaloosa, Santa Rosa, and Walton counties for an extended period.  Court officials also confirmed that all facilities remained open without interruption, and the court is not interested in the ransom demands from the ALPHV ransomware attack. The BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group emerged in November 2021 as a rebranding of DarkSide/BlackMatter. Initially known as DarkSide, it rebranded as BlackMatter in July 2021 before operations ceased in November 2021.  As BleepingComputer reported last week, the ALPHV ransomware attack on MGM Resorts resulted in losses of approximately 100 million dollars. Interpol Dismantles Phone Scam Network

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 330/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 4, 2023.  An international police operation has arrested dozens of suspects, including the ringleader of a criminal group that targeted elderly victims with phone scams.  The National Crime Agency (NCA) arrested the suspected ringleader near London, while Polish and German officers searched several locations in Europe.  Seized items include mobile phones and other electronic devices, gold bars and coins, jewelry, and €160,000 ($174,000) in cash.  Around 70 criminals have been arrested for investigation.  The scam's first step involved calling elderly victims, impersonating police officers or government officials, and informing them that their relatives were responsible for accidents resulting in fatalities. The call would then be transferred to a second individual who would cry and plead for help, shocking the recipient into complying with the scammers' demands to send money to avoid the relative's detainment.  The second step involved sending someone to collect the money directly from the victim's home. Europol estimates that hundreds of elderly victims were affected by this gang, losing up to €5 million ($5.4 million). Police claim the arrests have potentially prevented further losses of up to €1.4 million ($1.5 million).

Russia's state-owned Sberbank hit by 1 million RPS DDoS attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 486/66 (IT) Friday, November 10, 2023. Sberbank, a Russian financial institution, announced that it had faced the most intense Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack two weeks ago.  Sberbank is a majority state-owned banking and financial services company and the largest institution in Russia, holding about one-third of all assets in the country.  Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the bank has faced international sanctions and has been the target of hacktivists several times.  Russian news agency Interfax reported that the attack reached one million requests per second (RPS). The latest damage caused Russia's financial system related to the National Payment Card System (NSPK), the provider of Mir cards, to become unavailable on October 30, 2023. They later deleted a post about a data breach affecting customers.  The NSPK told the media that the attackers were unable to steal sensitive customer data, as the website did not store such information, and assured that the cyberattack did not affect the payment system. TheRecord later reported that hacktivists from the 'DumpForums' group and the Ukrainian Alliance Cyber Alliance claimed responsibility for the attack, claiming to have stolen 31 GB of data. Resecurity's HUNTER unit has detected the developers of MEDUZA STEALER, a tool used for stealing information, have launched a new version (2.2). This version has significant improvements, including support for more client software (including browser-based cryptocurrency wallets), an upgraded credit card (CC) grabber, and additional advanced operations for transferring password storage data on various platforms to extract credentials and tokens. Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking # Description : 
The product relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations, but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
Attackers can easily modify cookies, within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Reliance on cookies without detailed validation and integrity checking can allow attackers to bypass authentication, conduct injection attacks such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting, or otherwise modify inputs in unexpected ways.

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Architecture and Design
Avoid using cookie data for a security-related decision.
Phase: Implementation
Perform thorough input validation (i.e.: server side validation) on the cookie data if you're going to use it for a security related decision.
Phase: Architecture and Design
Add integrity checks to detect tampering.
Phase: Architecture and Design
Protect critical cookies from replay attacks, since cross-site scripting or other attacks may allow attackers to steal a strongly-encrypted cookie that also passes integrity checks. This mitigation applies to cookies that should only be valid during a single transaction or session. By enforcing timeouts, you may limit the scope of an attack. As part of your integrity check, use an unpredictable, server-side value that is not exposed to the client.
 URL: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/565.html

Save the date! 30th June -  workshop for the Trust Services Market
 is organising a workshop for the Trust Services market in Brussels on June 30th, 2015.

Trust service providers, conformity assessment bodies and supervisory authorities are invited to participate.
The workshop will focus on collaboration in frame of the eIDAS Regulation through panels and breakout sessions. The meeting aims to:
share good practices and experience as well as views on various aspects of the implementation of eIDAS by the relevant stakeholders and their compliance to EU legislation
understand the priorities and needs of trust service providers in the development of the eIDAS regulation.
exchange ideas on the positions of the different stakeholders in aspects like standards, certification, qualification, etc.
discuss strategies to promote the use qualified trust services in Europe.
Registration is now open and free of charge.
Please register
here
For more information:
Trust Services Forum
Background:
This year  in collaboration with the European Commission, is launching a Forum bringing together the three stakeholder communities in the qualified trust service market: trust service providers, conformity assessment bodies and supervisory authorities. The creation of this Forum has been motivated by the need for open discussion after the entry into force of the Regulation 910/2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market.
The Regulation has introduced new provisions that will facilitate harmonization and EU wide recognition of trust service providers, ensuring homogenous security levels and increasing market transparency. The eIDAS Regulation also foresees a permanent supervision of qualified providers, as well as periodical audits by conformity assessment bodies.
The aim is for providers to be able to discuss with regulatory and supervisory authorities how to facilitate compliance by aligning regulatory developments with the current market good practices, and how to increase market penetration of qualified trust services, as it is key to ensure a viable business model for qualified trust service providers, through an increased use of these services among European citizens, businesses and public administrations. The Israeli army penetrated the communications network of the Beirut airport control tower to warn Iranian planes not to land.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 345/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 1, 2024.  Last Saturday, the Israeli army penetrated the communications network of the Rafic Hariri International Airport control tower in Beirut, Lebanon, and sent warnings to Iranian civilian aircraft attempting to land, forcing the aircraft to return to Tehran, according to a report from the MiddleEastMonitor website.  The Lebanese Ministry of Transport ordered airport officials to prevent Iranian aircraft from entering Lebanese airspace after the Israeli infiltration. This decision follows warnings from the Israeli army to prevent the transport of weapons to Hezbollah through Beirut Airport.  Daniel Hagari, an Israeli army spokesperson, said in a statement: "We will not allow the transfer of weapons to Hezbollah in any form. We are aware of arms shipments from Iran to Hezbollah, and we will act to thwart them."  He added: "This airport is a civilian airport for civilian use, and it must remain so."  Ali Hamieh, the Lebanese Minister of Transport, confirmed to the newspaper "An-Nahar" that the Israeli army had penetrated the airport's control tower communication system and threatened to attack the infrastructure if Iranian planes landed.  The Israeli army claims that Beirut airport is being used as a transit point for weapons to Hezbollah, but Lebanese authorities have denied this accusation, insisting that the airport is for civilian use only. Malware Analysis Report
AMAR-231099-1.v1 - BangkokShell

Sophisticated malware was used to achieve cyber espionage objectives.  TTC-CERT previously analyzed malware related to the BangkokShell campaign in "Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230499-1.v2 - BangkokShell," which readers can find on the TTC-CERT website.²

Upon examining the suspicious files, TTC-CERT found that the Loader and Payload files were created in February 2021 (Compile Date).  The malware files found in Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230499-1.v2 - BangkokShell (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1o2uSDksXRG8RPTn7HW4jNCvuoPQMccxj/view) were created in December 2021.  Based on this information, it can be estimated that the suspicious files used in this attack are an earlier version of the malware previously detected in Malware Analysis Report AMAR-230499-1.v2 - BangkokShell. However, the Compile Date found in this instance could have been modified by the attackers.

In this attack, the process began with the use of DLL Side-loading to load a Dynamic Link Library (DLL) file named Lightshot.dll, which is a Loader-type malware. This Loader then deobfuscates the malware configuration embedded within the DLL file.  It then loads a file named Arials.ttf from the filesystem into memory. This file is the obfuscated RahadRAT malware, which is subsequently deobfuscated using the XOR Cipher algorithm and executed in memory using the Reflective Code Loading technique.
 URL: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1B_OPJ02FsG-lfHbfEJER0eub1NOgtxdHSVuhLcgVG3U/edit?tab=t.0

Adversary-in-the-Middle: DHCP Spoofing is techniques, 

Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as 
 or 
.
DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.
 The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 
Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.
 Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network.
DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a 
 message to the 
 multicast address.
 Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations.
Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, 
) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool.

Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment is techniques, 

Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious attachment in an attempt to gain access to victim systems. Spearphishing attachment is a specific variant of spearphishing. Spearphishing attachment is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of malware attached to an email. All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries attach a file to the spearphishing email and usually rely upon 
 to gain execution.
 Spearphishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.
There are many options for the attachment such as Microsoft Office documents, executables, PDFs, or archived files. Upon opening the attachment (and potentially clicking past protections), the adversary's payload exploits a vulnerability or directly executes on the user's system. The text of the spearphishing email usually tries to give a plausible reason why the file should be opened, and may explain how to bypass system protections in order to do so. The email may also contain instructions on how to decrypt an attachment, such as a zip file password, in order to evade email boundary defenses. Adversaries frequently manipulate file extensions and icons in order to make attached executables appear to be document files, or files exploiting one application appear to be a file for a different one.

E-Root Marketplace administrator sentenced to 42 months for selling 350,000 stolen credentials.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 109/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 20, 2024.  31-year-old Sandu Boris Diaconu was sentenced to 42 months in prison in the U.S. for operating an illegal marketplace called E-Root Marketplace, which offered 350,000 stolen credentials for sale. He was charged with conspiracy to commit access device fraud and computer fraud, and possession of 15 or more unauthorized access devices. He pleaded guilty on December 1, 2023.  The E-Root Marketplace operated through a widely distributed network and was able to hide the identities of administrators, buyers, and sellers. Buyers could search for compromised computer credentials on E-Root, such as usernames and passwords, that would allow buyers to remotely access computers for the purpose of stealing personal information or manipulating computer content remotely. The marketplace also concealed transaction paths by using an online payment system called Perfect Money, which allowed Bitcoin to be converted to Perfect Money.  The infrastructure associated with E-Root and Perfect Money was seized by law enforcement in late 2020.  It is estimated that more than 350,000 credentials were advertised for sale in the illegal marketplace, with many victims falling under ransomware attacks and tax fraud schemes.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/03/20/%e0%b8%9c%e0%b8%b9%e0%b9%89%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%b9%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b0%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%9a-e-root-marketplace-%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%b9%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%99/

Exploitation of Remote Services is techniques, 

Adversaries may exploit remote services of enterprise servers, workstations, or other resources to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a network. Adversaries may exploit remote services by taking advantage of a mobile device’s access to an internal enterprise network through local connectivity or through a Virtual Private Network (VPN). Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. A common goal for post-compromise exploitation of remote services is for lateral movement to enable access to a remote system. 
An adversary may need to determine if the remote system is in a vulnerable state, which may be done through 
 or other Discovery methods. These look for common, vulnerable software that may be deployed in the network, the lack of certain patches that may indicate vulnerabilities, or security software that may be used to detect or contain remote exploitation. Servers are likely a high value target for lateral movement exploitation, but endpoint systems may also be at risk if they provide an advantage or access to additional resources.
Depending on the permissions level of the vulnerable remote service, an adversary may achieve 
 as a result of lateral movement exploitation as well.

Mozilla warns users to update Firefox after a serious security vulnerability is exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 360/67 (IT) Friday, October 11, 2024. Mozilla revealed that Firefox and Firefox Extended Support Release (ESR) are facing attacks exploiting a critical security vulnerability, CVE-2024-9680. This flaw exists in the browser's timeline animation component.  This vulnerability allows attackers to execute malicious code within the browser's content process.  Damien Schaeffer, a security researcher at ESET, discovered and reported the vulnerability. The issue has been fixed in Firefox version 131.0.2, Firefox ESR 128.3.1, and Firefox ESR 115.16.1. Although there is currently no clear information on how malicious actors are exploiting this vulnerability, Mozilla warns that attackers could weaponize the flaw in various attack forms such as Watering Hole attacks or deceptive downloads.  Therefore, Mozilla recommends that users update Firefox to the latest version as soon as possible to prevent attacks exploiting this vulnerability. Barracuda recommends immediate replacement of hacked ESG appliances.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 295/66 (IT) Friday, June 9, 2023. Barracuda, an email protection and network security provider, advises customers affected by the Zero-day vulnerability in Email Security Gateway (ESG) appliances to replace those devices immediately. The company stated in an update that affected ESG appliances must be replaced immediately, regardless of patching the vulnerability.  The issue arose when Barracuda disclosed a critical vulnerability in the devices (CVE-2023-2868, CVSS score: 9.8) that had been exploited by malicious actors for at least seven months, since October 2022, to deploy malware and steal data. The vulnerability involves remote code injection affecting versions 5.1.3.001 to 9.2.0.006, stemming from incomplete validation of attachments within inbound emails.  It was patched on May 20 and 21, 2023.  Three distinct malware families currently discovered come with capabilities to arbitrarily upload or download files, execute commands, and establish reverse shells to attacker-controlled servers.  The exact scope of the incident remains unknown, but the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has advised federal agencies to remediate by June 16, 2023.

Fortinet releases patches to fix RCE vulnerability in Fortigate SSL-VPN devices, which should be patched immediately.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 299/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 13, 2023. Fortinet has released new Fortigate firmware patches that address a vulnerability that could be exploited by attackers to remotely execute code. This is critical in SSL VPN devices. The security fix was released last Friday in FortiOS firmware versions 6.0.17, 6.2.15, 6.4.13, 7.0.12, and 7.2.5. The vulnerability allows attackers to attack via VPN even if users have multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled. Fortinet devices are among the most popular firewall and VPN devices on the market, making them a popular target for attackers.  A Shodan search shows more than 250,000 Fortigate firewalls accessible from the internet. Since this vulnerability affects all previous versions, administrators should expedite patching and update Fortinet security as soon as it is available. A cyberattack occurred at Beirut International Airport, the capital of Lebanon. The attackers compromised the Flight Information Display System (FIDS).

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 11/67 (IT) reported on Tuesday, January 9, 2024, that hackers attacked Beirut-Rafic Al Hariri International Airport in Lebanon and breached the Flight Information Display System (FIDS). Rafic Hariri International Airport is the main international airport serving Beirut, the capital of Lebanon.  The airport is named after former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri and is located approximately 9 kilometers from downtown Beirut. The airport is a major gateway for both domestic and international air travel.  The cyberattack involved hackers posting messages on screens in the airport. The messages claimed that Hezbollah and Iran are pushing the country towards war, disregarding the Lebanese people. The messages also mentioned the smuggling of weapons to be used for bombing the airport.  According to local television station LBCI, the cyberattack also disrupted the baggage screening system, known as the Baggage Handling System (BHS). Airport officials had to use police dogs to complete baggage checks. The cyberattack comes amid heightened tensions between Israel and Lebanon. However, no hacker group has claimed responsibility for the attack so far.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/01/09/%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b5%e0%b8%97%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%8b%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c/

Adversaries may configure system settings to automatically execute a program during system boot or logon to maintain persistence or gain higher-level privileges on compromised systems. Operating systems may have mechanisms for automatically running a program on system boot or account logon.
 These mechanisms may include automatically executing programs that are placed in specially designated directories or are referenced by repositories that store configuration information, such as the Windows Registry. An adversary may achieve the same goal by modifying or extending features of the kernel.
Since some boot or logon autostart programs run with higher privileges, an adversary may leverage these to elevate privileges.

Modify Controller Tasking is techniques, 

Adversaries may modify the tasking of a controller to allow for the execution of their own programs. This can allow an adversary to manipulate the execution flow and behavior of a controller. 
According to 61131-3, the association of a Task with a Program Organization Unit (POU) defines a task association. 
 An adversary may modify these associations or create new ones to manipulate the execution flow of a controller. Modification of controller tasking can be accomplished using a Program Download in addition to other types of program modification such as online edit and program append.
Tasks have properties, such as interval, frequency and priority to meet the requirements of program execution. Some controller vendors implement tasks with implicit, pre-defined properties whereas others allow for these properties to be formulated explicitly. An adversary may associate their program with tasks that have a higher priority or execute associated programs more frequently. For instance, to ensure cyclic execution of their program on a Siemens controller, an adversary may add their program to the task, Organization Block 1 (OB1).

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 325/67 (IT) Monday, September 16, 2024. GitLab released security patches to address 17 vulnerabilities in GitLab CE (Community Edition) and EE (Enterprise Edition). CISA adds Oracle WebLogic Server OS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 198/67 (IT) Wednesday, June 5, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added an Oracle WebLogic Server OS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The vulnerability, CVE-2017-3506 (CVSS score 7.4), is an OS command injection vulnerability affecting Oracle WebLogic Server OS versions 10.3.6.0, 12.1.3.0, 12.2.1.0, 12.2.1.1, and 12.2.1.2.  An unauthenticated attacker can gain network access by exploiting the vulnerability via HTTP to compromise the Oracle WebLogic Server. Successful exploitation could lead to unauthorized creation, deletion, or modification of sensitive data, as well as unauthorized access to all data accessible by the Oracle WebLogic Server. To mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are required to remediate the identified vulnerability by the due date. To prevent attacks and exploitation of this vulnerability, experts recommend that private sector organizations also review the catalog and address the vulnerability. CISA has mandated that government agencies remediate this vulnerability by June 24, 2024. Cyberattack disrupts LYCA MOBILE services

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 442/66 (IT) Friday, October 6, 2023 Lyca Mobile, an international mobile virtual network operator, has been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. Lyca Mobile is a Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNO) that provides prepaid mobile phone services to customers in many countries around the world. The company does not own the wireless network infrastructure, but leases network services from mobile operators instead, and Lycamobile serves more than 60 countries, reaching more than 15 million prepaid customers worldwide. The company issued a statement announcing that it had been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. The cyberattack occurred last week, preventing customers from accessing top-ups through the company's channels. The cyberattack did not affect services in the United States, Australia, Tunisia, and Ukraine. The company has investigated the security breach with the support of technical experts and has notified relevant regulatory and law enforcement agencies in each affected market. The company announced that it has restored affected services in all markets, but some operational services have not yet been resolved.  The company did not provide details about the attack, but it is likely that the company was hit by Ransomware. Notification - Analysis Report: Further Tracking of Command and Control (C2) Infrastructure and Operations Used in Mustang Panda Attacks

The TTC-CERT Center has noted a report from Unit 42, which identified three cyber attack campaigns by the Mustang Panda group in August 2023, targeting various entities in the South Pacific, including the Philippine government.  In these campaigns, the attackers embedded malware within commonly used software by loading malicious files through software named Solid PDF Creator and SmadavProtect (an Indonesian antivirus solution).  These operations, linked to Mustang Panda, demonstrate the objective of continuous cyber espionage.  The report indicates that the attackers successfully infiltrated Philippine government agencies.

Mustang Panda's latest cyber espionage attacks have revealed sophisticated methods of infiltrating computer networks of government agencies and various organizations. While Mustang Panda's campaigns have been widely discussed, a thorough examination of their cyber operations and Command and Control (C2) infrastructure characteristics has informed TTC-CERT about the attackers' methods and revealed a Command and Control (C2) server infrastructure (potentially for use in future attacks) linked to the C2 infrastructure identified in the Unit 42 report.

FSB arrests Russian hackers working for Ukrainian cyber forces. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 475/66 (IT) Friday, November 3, 2023. The Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) announced and released a statement on Tuesday stating that officers arrested two hackers believed to be assisting Ukrainian forces in carrying out cyberattacks against critical infrastructure targets in Russia.  The two suspects were detained on the same day but in different areas of Siberia. Both were charged with the serious crime of treason, which carries a maximum sentence of 20 years.  One suspect is a student at Tomsk State University of Control Systems and Radio Electronics. Russian media said the investigation found that he had helped a group of Ukrainian hackers in cyberattacks on Russian data infrastructure networks. He was put on a plane and sent to a pre-trial detention center in Lefortovo, Moscow, known as the infamous KGB prison and the former interrogation site for political prisoners. The second suspect is a 36-year-old man from the small town of Belovo, believed to be a member of Ukraine's cyber unit. He is believed to have been involved in cyber operations linked to Ukrainian forces, using malware and cyberattacks to disrupt critical infrastructure networks in Russia. Email Collection: Email Forwarding Rule is techniques, 

Adversaries may setup email forwarding rules to collect sensitive information. Adversaries may abuse email forwarding rules to monitor the activities of a victim, steal information, and further gain intelligence on the victim or the victim’s organization to use as part of further exploits or operations.
 Furthermore, email forwarding rules can allow adversaries to maintain persistent access to victim's emails even after compromised credentials are reset by administrators.
 Most email clients allow users to create inbox rules for various email functions, including forwarding to a different recipient. These rules may be created through a local email application, a web interface, or by command-line interface. Messages can be forwarded to internal or external recipients, and there are no restrictions limiting the extent of this rule. Administrators may also create forwarding rules for user accounts with the same considerations and outcomes.
Any user or administrator within the organization (or adversary with valid credentials) can create rules to automatically forward all received messages to another recipient, forward emails to different locations based on the sender, and more. Adversaries may also hide the rule by making use of the Microsoft Messaging API (MAPI) to modify the rule properties, making it hidden and not visible from Outlook, OWA or most Exchange Administration tools.
In some environments, administrators may be able to enable email forwarding rules that operate organization-wide rather than on individual inboxes. For example, Microsoft Exchange supports transport rules that evaluate all mail an organization receives against user-specified conditions, then performs a user-specified action on mail that adheres to those conditions.
 Adversaries that abuse such features may be able to enable forwarding on all or specific mail an organization receives. 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1114/003/

Preliminary Malware Analysis Report IMAR-220999-1.v1 - Agenda Golang Ransomware

The TTC-CERT Center has analyzed a suspicious file received from the National Cyber Security Committee (NCSC). Preliminary information indicates that the file was found in the %Public% directory on a server hosting Active Directory (AD) and was attacked by ransomware.

Static and Behavior Analysis revealed that the file is ransomware developed using the Golang language. TTC-CERT suspects the attackers chose Golang because its source code can be compiled into binaries for various operating systems like Windows, Linux, and macOS, saving development time.  Furthermore, malware compiled with the Golang compiler can run on target machines with minimal reliance on operating system APIs, increasing the likelihood of successful attacks while leaving fewer traces compared to scripting languages like Python.

This ransomware is configured to target specific victims and has various capabilities beyond encrypting files on the target machine.  It can also encrypt files stored on network drives connected to the target computer and directs victims to pay the ransom through the attacker's website on the Tor network.

Other capabilities identified through behavior analysis include the ability to accept parameters from Registry Keys, resulting in different behaviors based on the defined parameters. The malware can also delete Shadow Copies to prevent system or data recovery.  Additionally, it can disable numerous Windows Services and Processes related to security, including the capability to attack via Network and Local Accounts with Administrator privileges.

London Drugs pharmacy chain closes stores after cyberattack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 158/67 (IT) Wednesday, May 1, 2024. On April 28, 2024, London Drugs discovered it was the victim of a cyberattack, closing all of its retail locations across Canada to contain the cyber incident. welcomes Greek government VIPs
The Greek Minister of Transport, Infrastructure and Networks, Mr. Mavroudis Voridis
and an accompanying delegation visited  on 28th, December to learn more in
detail of the Agency's operations.

 welcomed a Greek government delegation to its Heraklion offices on 28th December to show them how the agency’s work is improving network and information security for Europe’s citizens.
The group was led by Minister of Transport, Infrastructure and Networks, Mr Mavroudis Voridis. It also included Secretary General for Communications Mr Socrates Katsikas, Legal Adviser to the Minister, Mr Fedon Dimopoulos, Head of International Relations Department, Mr Ilias Pantazis and Greece’s National Representative to the Management Board of , Professor Constantine Stefanidis.
During the visit, the delegation saw a presentation on ’s latest work, which includes ’s 2011 work and support for the Member States e.g. EP3R, CIIP, Exercises, CERTs and an outlook for the 2012 Work-Programme. They also learnt about how  collaborates with EU Member State governments, the IT security industry and other stakeholders,  to tackle current and future threats.
’s Executive Director, Professor Udo Helmbrecht, and the Agency’s Head of Unit for Secure Services, Dr Demosthenes Ikonomou hosted the visit. Professor Helmbrecht said: “ has taken a number of initiatives in recent months to help us focus on improving IT security. For example, earlier this year, we created our Mobile Assistance Team, which helps us to work more closely with our stakeholders across EU Member States. The visit from Mr Mavroudis and his party was an excellent opportunity for us to share these latest developments with him and his group, and discuss how we can collaborate more closely to enhance network and information security for all of Europe’s citizens.” URL: https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/enisa-welcomes-greek-government-vips

CHAVECLOAK is a new banking Trojan targeting Brazilian users via phishing attacks.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 99/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 13, 2024:  Users in Brazil are being targeted by a new banking Trojan called CHAVECLOAK, which is spread through phishing emails containing PDF attachments.  These emails trick users into downloading a ZIP file and subsequently use DLL side-loading techniques to finally install the malware. The attack chain involves the use of DocuSign-themed lures (electronic signature transaction management system) to trick users into opening a PDF file with a button to read and sign a document. Clicking this button leads to the retrieval of an installer file from a shortened link using the Goo.su URL shortening service.  Inside the installer is an executable file named "Lightshot.exe," which utilizes DLL side-loading to load "Lightshot.dll," which is the CHAVECLOAK malware. This allows attackers to steal sensitive information, log keystrokes, and display deceptive pop-up windows to victims. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 142/67 (IT) Thursday, April 18, 2024 Cisco has issued a warning about a global increase in brute-force attacks targeting various devices, including Virtual Private Network (VPN) services, web application monitoring interfaces, and SSH services since March 18, 2024. Successful attacks can lead to unauthorized network access, account lockout, or denial of service. Targeted devices include: – Cisco Secure Firewall VPN – Checkpoint VPN – Fortinet VPN – SonicWall VPN – RD Web Services – Mikrotik – Draytek – Ubiquiti. The annual  Industry Event took place today in Brussels, Belgium, and saw the participation of over 70 representatives of the Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) community active in cybersecurity in the EU.

Steve Purser,  Head of Core Operations Department said: “We discussed about ’s continuous efforts to cooperate with and strengthen the EU SME community, touching upon important topics such as the cyber threat intelligence capability framework and maturity model, the technological foresight methodology and also funding of regional cooperation and incubators. We also exchanged views about business opportunities that might arise from the recently launched proposal to set up a cybersecurity competence network and centre. Our Agency is fully committed to supporting the SME community in all these regards.”
The main point of the industry event was the discussion panel on regional cybersecurity collaboration, where representatives from the public and private sector including the European Commission presented their views and shared best practices and successful initiatives.

Experts warn ransomware groups are exploiting vulnerabilities in Atlassian and Apache.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 481/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 8, 2023. Rapid7, a cybersecurity firm, has observed multiple ransomware groups starting to exploit recently disclosed vulnerabilities in Atlassian Confluence and Apache ActiveMQ, vulnerability numbers CVE-2023-22518 and CVE-2023-22515. Both vulnerabilities are critical, allowing attackers to create unauthorized Confluence administrator accounts and cause data loss.  On November 6, Atlassian updated its advisory, noting multiple instances of the vulnerability being exploited and is adjusting the vulnerability's CVSS score from 9.8 to 10.0, indicating maximum severity.  The escalation is due to a change in the attack scope, with numerous threat actors and exploits targeting vulnerable internet-facing Atlassian Confluence servers to retrieve malicious payloads hosted on remote servers, which leads to the execution of ransomware payloads on compromised servers.  Data collected by GreyNoise indicates that exploitation attempts originate from IP addresses in three different countries: France, Hong Kong, and Russia. Heads of EU Agencies meet Barroso
The Heads of the EU Agencies, met on 17 February with the European Commission President José Manuel Barroso. The objective is to discuss ways to strengthen the partnership between EU Agencies and the European Commission, the European Parliament and the Council. Moreover, they will share their views on the EU’s future approach to the governance of the Agencies.

Mr. Barroso, President of the European Commission, will deliver a keynote speech, highlighting the role and contribution of EU regulatory agencies in the context of a future framework for the EU regulatory agencies.
In its press release“
European agencies – the way forward
” of March 2008, the European Commission called upon the European Parliament and Council to give a new momentum to the development of a clear and coherent vision on the place of agencies in European governance.
Discussions at the Heads of EU agencies meeting will feed into the inter-institutional dialogue on the future governance of the EU Agencies. This includes an evaluation of existing agencies and reflections on changes which could be made to improve the system in the future.
Representatives from the European Parliament and from the Spanish Presidency of the European Union will also attend the meeting.

LockBit ransomware group is back in action with a new encryptor and servers.

Last week, law enforcement agencies NCA, FBI, and Europol carried out a joint operation called 'Operation Cronos' to suppress the LockBit ransomware group. In this operation, law enforcement seized infrastructure, decryptor data, and shut down the LockBit website used for leaking stolen data.  However, the LockBit ransomware group is returning to attacks, using a newly updated encryptor and a new server infrastructure setup for publishing leaks and ransom negotiations.

According to BleepingComputer, the operation's negotiation server is back online but is only functional for victims of new attacks. While LockBit was being suppressed, approximately 180 affiliated cybercriminal groups continued ransomware operations. It is unclear how many are still working together in a Ransomware-as-a-Service model, as one publicly disclosed their operation on X. However, LockBit states that they are currently recruiting experienced pentesters to rejoin the operation, which may lead to increased attacks in the future. Critical vulnerability alert in VMware Aria Operations Networks, risk of remote attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/66 (IT) Thursday, August 31, 2023. VMware has released software updates to address two security vulnerabilities in Aria Operations for Networks that could be exploited to bypass authentication and allow remote code execution. The most severe vulnerability, CVE-2023-34039 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers with network access to Aria Operations for Networks to bypass SSH authentication to access the Aria Operations for Networks CLI. The vulnerability was reported by researchers Harsh Jaiswal and Rahul Maini, who are credited with its discovery.  The second vulnerability, CVE-2023-20890 (CVSS score: 7.2), is an arbitrary file write vulnerability affecting Aria Operations for Networks. It could be exploited by attackers with admin privileges to write files to arbitrary locations and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerability was reported by Sina Kheirkhah of the Summoning team.  These vulnerabilities affect VMware Aria Operations Networks versions 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5.1, 6.6, 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, and 6.10. They have been addressed in VMware version 6.11.0, which fixes both vulnerabilities.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/08/31/%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%88%e0%b9%89%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b7%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88-critical-%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%99-vmware-aria-operat/

Deserialization of Untrusted Data # Description : 


# Extend Description : 


# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phases: Architecture and Design; Implementation
If available, use the signing/sealing features of the programming language to assure that deserialized data has not been tainted. For example, a hash-based message authentication code (HMAC) could be used to ensure that data has not been modified.
Phase: Implementation
When deserializing data, populate a new object rather than just deserializing. The result is that the data flows through safe input validation and that the functions are safe.
Phase: Implementation
Explicitly define a final object() to prevent deserialization.
Phases: Architecture and Design; Implementation
Make fields transient to protect them from deserialization.
An attempt to serialize and then deserialize a class containing transient fields will result in NULLs where the transient data should be. This is an excellent way to prevent time, environment-based, or sensitive variables from being carried over and used improperly.
Phase: Implementation
Avoid having unnecessary types or gadgets (a sequence of instances and method invocations that can self-execute during the deserialization process, often found in libraries) available that can be leveraged for malicious ends. This limits the potential for unintended or unauthorized types and gadgets to be leveraged by the attacker. Add only acceptable classes to an allowlist. Note: new gadgets are constantly being discovered, so this alone is not a sufficient mitigation.
Phases: Architecture and Design; Implementation
Employ cryptography of the data or code for protection. However, it's important to note that it would still be client-side security. This is risky because if the client is compromised then the security implemented on the client (the cryptography) can be bypassed.
 URL: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/502.html

A hosting company says it lost all customer data after a ransomware attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/66 (IT) on Thursday, August 24, 2023, reported that two Danish hosting companies suffered a ransomware attack, resulting in the loss of most customer data.  This forced the hosting providers to shut down all systems, including customer websites and emails. Both Hosting CloudNordic and AzeroCloud brands belong to the same company. The attack occurred last Friday night, and the company stated it would not pay the ransom. The company is cooperating with security experts and has reported the incident to the police.  Due to the situation, both hosting providers recommend heavily impacted customers migrate to other providers, such as Powernet and Nordicway.  Danish media reported that the attack affected hundreds of Danish companies, which lost data stored in the cloud, including websites, email inboxes, and documents. Targeting hosting providers is a tactic used by ransomware groups in the past, as it causes significant damage and allows them to attack many victims in a single attack. This incident has resulted in numerous victims, putting immense pressure on the providers to pay the ransom to restore operations and avoid lawsuits from customers who lost data. . While use of 
 may involve checking for known sandbox values and continuing with execution only if there is no match, the use of guardrails will involve checking for an expected target-specific value and only continuing with execution if there is such a match.

’s Annual Privacy Forum (APF) is to be held on the 13
th
and 14
th
June 2018 in Barcelona, in co-operation with the Polytechnic University of Catalonia (UPC) and Telefonica.
Call for papers
for APF 2018 is now open
.
Submission until 30
th
of March 2018.
Papers
presenting original work on the themes of data protection and privacy and their repercussions on technology, business, government, law, society and policy are invited. . In order to promote participation of young researchers, the submission of papers by students is encouraged. These papers will be treated as thoroughly as full papers, but can be shorter and reflect novel thinking that might not have been fully elaborated just yet.

. In addition to student papers, short papers are invited as this call is open to anyone who has a sketch of an idea, opinion or a call for collaboration.

Phishing for Information: Spearphishing Service is techniques, 

Adversaries may send spearphishing messages via third-party services to elicit sensitive information that can be used during targeting. Spearphishing for information is an attempt to trick targets into divulging information, frequently credentials or other actionable information. Spearphishing for information frequently involves social engineering techniques, such as posing as a source with a reason to collect information (ex: 
 or 
) and/or sending multiple, seemingly urgent messages.
All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries send messages through various social media services, personal webmail, and other non-enterprise controlled services.
 These services are more likely to have a less-strict security policy than an enterprise. As with most kinds of spearphishing, the goal is to generate rapport with the target or get the target's interest in some way. Adversaries may create fake social media accounts and message employees for potential job opportunities. Doing so allows a plausible reason for asking about services, policies, and information about their environment. Adversaries may also use information from previous reconnaissance efforts (ex: 
 or 
) to craft persuasive and believable lures.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/001/
