Warning! Scammers have a new trick to steal bank app access codes.

Warning! Scammers have a new trick to steal bank app access codes. The Thai Bankers' Association is warning the public about a new scam targeting people's money. This time, scammers impersonate various agencies and organizations by contacting people through LINE and using various deceptive tactics.  For example, they might pretend to be police officers, forcing victims to turn on their cameras for recording, claiming it's for evidence.  Or they might claim they will transfer money back to the victim and ask for personal information for verification.

Next, the scammers will trick the victim into a video call and then trick them into sharing their screen. They then instruct the victim to dial "131 followed by their bank app access code# and then press call," or some other number sequence that won't actually connect a call. This allows the scammer to see the code entered on the screen and use it to access the victim's banking app and steal their money.

The Thai Bankers' Association advises everyone to be vigilant and cautious, and not to fall for scammers who create situations to initiate video calls. Never give any personal information, including access codes, to anyone.  If you encounter online fraud, contact the AOC Center at 1441 for consultation, reporting, or assistance with online threats, 24 hours a day.

FBI shuts down dozens of Radar/Dispossessor ransomware servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 291/67 (IT) Thursday, August 15, 2024.  The FBI has shut down dozens of servers linked to the Radar/Dispossessor ransomware operation, a cybercriminal group that has become a significant threat recently. The group started by publishing data stolen by the LockBit ransomware group but has since evolved into an international ransomware gang targeting small to medium-sized businesses, including organizations across multiple sectors worldwide.  The FBI collaborated with law enforcement agencies from several countries to disrupt the group's infrastructure. Servers were shut down in the US, UK, and Germany, as well as criminal domains used in the attacks.  Radar/Dispossessor employs sophisticated attack methods, exploiting vulnerabilities and easily guessed passwords to access victims' systems. They then encrypt data and extort victims for ransom.  The criminals also contact victims' employees directly via email or phone to increase pressure to pay the ransom. The shutdown of Radar/Dispossessor is a law enforcement success, but experts warn that organizational self-defense remains crucial, as ransomware continues to be a widespread threat. Application Layer Protocol: Mail Protocols is techniques, 

Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with electronic mail delivery to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server. 
Protocols such as SMTP/S, POP3/S, and IMAP that carry electronic mail may be very common in environments.  Packets produced from these protocols may have many fields and headers in which data can be concealed. Data could also be concealed within the email messages themselves. An adversary may abuse these protocols to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network while also mimicking normal, expected traffic.

Adversaries may buy and/or steal code signing certificates that can be used during targeting. Code signing is the process of digitally signing executables and scripts to confirm the software author and guarantee that the code has not been altered or corrupted. Code signing provides a level of authenticity for a program from the developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with.
 Users and/or security tools may trust a signed piece of code more than an unsigned piece of code even if they don't know who issued the certificate or who the author is.
Prior to 
, adversaries may purchase or steal code signing certificates for use in operations. The purchase of code signing certificates may be done using a front organization or using information stolen from a previously compromised entity that allows the adversary to validate to a certificate provider as that entity. Adversaries may also steal code signing materials directly from a compromised third-party.

Network Sniffing is techniques, 

Network sniffing is the practice of using a network interface on a computer system to monitor or capture information 
 regardless of whether it is the specified destination for the information. 
An adversary may attempt to sniff the traffic to gain information about the target. This information can vary in the level of importance. Relatively unimportant information is general communications to and from machines.  Relatively important information would be login information. User credentials may be sent over an unencrypted protocol, such as Telnet, that can be captured and obtained through network packet analysis. 
In addition, ARP and Domain Name Service (DNS) poisoning can be used to capture credentials to websites, proxies, and internal systems by redirecting traffic to an adversary.

I/O Image is techniques, 

Adversaries may seek to capture process values related to the inputs and outputs of a PLC. During the scan cycle, a PLC reads the status of all inputs and stores them in an image table. 
 The image table is the PLCs internal storage location where values of inputs/outputs for one scan are stored while it executes the user program. After the PLC has solved the entire logic program, it updates the output image table. The contents of this output image table are written to the corresponding output points in I/O Modules.
The Input and Output Image tables described above make up the I/O Image on a PLC. This image is used by the user program instead of directly interacting with physical I/O. 
 
Adversaries may collect the I/O Image state of a PLC by utilizing a devices 
 to access the memory regions directly. The collection of the PLCs I/O state could be used to replace values or inform future stages of an attack.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T0877

A cyberattack on the American Radio Relay League (ARRL) has taken its Logbook of the World system offline.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Tuesday, May 21, 2024, that the ARRL announced it is experiencing a cyberattack that has disrupted its IT systems and online operations, including email and Logbook of the World. The ARRL represents amateur radio to government regulators, provides technical advice, and promotes activities and educational programs nationwide.  Last Thursday, the ARRL announced it had suffered a cyberattack that disrupted its network and systems, including various online services.  The ARRL is currently responding to the incident, which has impacted access to its network and systems at headquarters. Several services, such as Logbook of The World and the ARRL Learning Center, have been affected. In an update on Friday, the ARRL reported, to allay members' concerns about data security, that it does not store credit card information or social security numbers, and it is currently unclear whether it has experienced a ransomware attack or another type of cyber incident.  BleepingComputer has reached out to the ARRL for further comment but has not yet received a response. The situation reflects the complex threats affecting organizations and governments.  Because the Swiss government uses the services of Xplain, a Swiss technology service provider that provides software solutions to various government agencies, administrative units, and even the country's army. This group also claimed similar attacks against the Swiss parliament on June 7-8.

Web Service: Bidirectional Communication is techniques, 

Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service channel as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 
Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.

Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere # Description : 
The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
Resources such as files and directories may be inadvertently exposed through mechanisms such as insecure permissions, or when a program accidentally operates on the wrong object. For example, a program may intend that private files can only be provided to a specific user. This effectively defines a control sphere that is intended to prevent attackers from accessing these private files. If the file permissions are insecure, then parties other than the user will be able to access those files.
A separate control sphere might effectively require that the user can only access the private files, but not any other files on the system. If the program does not ensure that the user is only requesting private files, then the user might be able to access other files on the system.
In either case, the end result is that a resource has been exposed to the wrong party.

Broadcom releases updates to fix critical vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter Server. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 330/67 (IT) Thursday, September 19, 2024. Broadcom has released security updates to address critical vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter Server that could allow attackers to remotely execute code.  This vulnerability is tracked as CVE-2024-38812 and has a severity score of 9.8 out of 10, which could allow attackers with network access to compromise the system by sending specially crafted network packets. vCenter Server is a key component in managing VMware's virtualized data centers, which has a heap-overflow vulnerability affecting the DCERPC protocol implementation. In addition, Broadcom has also addressed a privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2024-38813) that could allow attackers to gain root privileges. Both vulnerabilities were discovered by the TZL team during the Matrix Cup 2024 competition. Broadcom has released updates to fix these issues in vCenter Server versions 8.0 U3b and 7.0 U3s, along with relevant versions of VMware Cloud Foundation. Although no exploits targeting these vulnerabilities have been observed yet, Broadcom recommends users update their systems immediately to mitigate the risks. The LockBit group demanded a $70 million ransom from semiconductor manufacturing giant TSMC.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 328/66 (IT) for Monday, July 3, 2023, reported that the LockBit ransomware group claimed to have penetrated the systems of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and demanded a ransom of $70 million. TSMC is the world's largest chip manufacturer for the technology sector, including Apple and Qualcomm Inc.  On Wednesday, BleepingComputer reported that a Lockbit affiliate called Bassterlord announced the attack on TSMC via Twitter and published images containing company-related data as proof of the attack. The group claimed to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatened to publish it if payment was refused.  The group initially gave TSMC seven days to pay the ransom but later extended the deadline to August 6. TSMC denied being breached by Lockbit but confirmed that the group had breached Kinmax Technology, one of its IT hardware suppliers. The investigation into the incident revealed no impact on TSMC's core operations and no compromise of TSMC customer data. TSMC stated it would not work with the compromised supplier until the situation was resolved. Taiwan's Kinmax Technology also provides services to other prominent companies such as Cisco, Citrix, HPE, Microsoft, and Nvidia. The security breach was discovered on June 29.

Is e-data the new currency? New  report looks at privacy and tracking
Internet users are increasingly tracked and profiled, with personal data being treated as currency in exchange for services. A gap exists between the legal requirements for personal data protection and the practice in the online environment.

The new Regulation proposal by the European Commission (COM2012/11/final), aims to address these challenges from a legal perspective. This 
study
provides a technical aspect on behavioural tracking, identifying the need for an interdisciplinary approach to address the privacy risks associated with tracking mechanisms.
Risks from tracking include global surveillance by governments and companies; service and price discrimination; and personalisation risks from data filtering. Protective measures are focused at a technological, legislative and educational level. ’s recommendations are addressed to regulators, policy stakeholders, researchers and developers. These proposals include: anti-tracking initiatives and solutions for mobile applications; development of easy-to-use tools for transparency and control; enforcement of compliance with rules and regulations on personal data protection monitoring and detecting violations; and promoting privacy-by-design to ensure meaningful privacy policies.
For the
full report URL: https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/is-e-data-the-new-currency-new-enisa-report-looks-at-privacy-and-tracking

CISA warns of Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 being exploited by Ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 68/67 (IT) Monday, February 19, 2024.  The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns that the Akira Ransomware group is exploiting the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 (CVSS score: 7.5) which is commonly exploited, and CISA has added the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 is an information disclosure vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco ASA/FTD. CISA mentioned that the vulnerability is being used in Ransomware campaigns, but did not disclose which Ransomware groups are exploiting it. In January, researchers from cybersecurity firm Truesec reported forensic data showing the Akira Ransomware group exploiting the Cisco ASA (Adaptive Security Appliance) and FTD (Firepower Threat Defence) vulnerability. Attackers can use the vulnerability to extract sensitive information from the device's memory, including usernames and passwords. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch the CVE-2020-3259 vulnerability by March 7, 2024, and advised private sector organizations to inspect and patch the vulnerability in their infrastructure as well. International Monetary Fund (IMF) Email Accounts Compromised

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 108/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 19, 2024. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has disclosed a security breach by a Threat Actor who compromised 11 email accounts earlier this year. The agency discovered the incident on February 16, 2024, and immediately launched an investigation with the assistance of cybersecurity experts.  The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a major financial agency of the United Nations and an international financial institution funded by 190 member countries. Its mission is “working to foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world.”  The investigation into the 11 compromised IMF email accounts affected has so far not revealed any additional indicators or evidence, and the investigation is ongoing. This incident is not the first time the IMF has faced such problems; the IMF experienced a major security breach in 2011. Securing EU Institutions, Bodies and Agencies
Today, the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity () welcomes the recommendations of the European Court of Auditors on cybersecurity of EUIBAs.

The observations and recommendations of the European Court of Auditors’ special report on the cybersecurity of EU institutions, bodies and agencies come at a timely moment, as cyber threats are increasing and discussions about cyber preparedness are taking place across numerous EU communities.
The report highlights the key roles that  and CERT-EU can play in increasing the level of cyber preparedness of EUIBAs as a whole and underscores the need for adequate resources to do so. Furthermore, the findings and recommendations of the report underline the importance of common legal cybersecurity frameworks for all EUIBAs.
The observations arrive just as the European Commission has proposed a regulation on measures for a high common level of cybersecurity at the EU institutions, bodies and agencies. The regulation aims to establish common cybersecurity measures to boost the resilience and response capacities against cyber threats and incidents.
Background
In 2021, the EU Agency for Cybersecurity and CERT-EU signed an agreement on a structured cooperation to work together on capacity building, operational cooperation and knowledge and information sharing. The provision for a structured cooperation was included in the Cybersecurity Act of 2019.  and CERT-EU meet regularly to agree on joint activities to implement the Annual Cooperation Plans.

GoTitan botnet spotted exploiting recent Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 513/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. A recently disclosed security vulnerability affecting Apache ActiveMQ is being exploited by attackers to spread a new Go-based botnet called GoTitan, as well as a .NET program known as PrCtrl Rat, which can remotely control malware-infected hosts.  The attack involves exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS score: 10.0) that has been used in attacks by various hacker groups, including the Lazarus group, in recent weeks. After a successful breach, the threat actors are found to drop further payloads from remote servers. One of these is GoTitan, a botnet designed to orchestrate distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks via protocols such as HTTP, UDP, TCP, and TLS. Fortinet has also observed cases where vulnerable Apache ActiveMQ servers are being targeted to deploy another DDoS botnet called Ddostf, Kinsing malware for cryptojacking, and a command-and-control (C2) framework named Sliver. Another prominent malware delivered is a remote access trojan called PrCtrl Rat that establishes contact with a C2 server to receive further instructions for actions on the system, such as collecting data files and downloading and uploading files from the server. Command and Control is tactics, 

The adversary is trying to communicate with and control compromised systems, controllers, and platforms with access to your ICS environment.
Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries use to communicate with and send commands to compromised systems, devices, controllers, and platforms with specialized applications used in ICS environments. Examples of these specialized communication devices include human machine interfaces (HMIs), data historians, SCADA servers, and engineering workstations (EWS). Adversaries often seek to use commonly available resources and mimic expected network traffic to avoid detection and suspicion. For instance, commonly used ports and protocols in ICS environments, and even expected IT resources, depending on the target network. Command and Control may be established to varying degrees of stealth, often depending on the victim’s network structure and defenses.

Agency Cloud Computing reports recognised by Danish Data Protection Authority
The Danish Data Protection Agency has published an opinion concerning cloud computing, and points to 's Cloud Computing reports as corner stones for informed decision making.

On 3 February 2011 the Danish Data Protection Agency (DDPA) published an opinion concerning cloud computing.
The opinion was (one of) the first of its kind issued by a European Data Protection authority. It therefore has a general interest for stakeholders within the cloud arena.

In the opinion, the Danish Data Protection Agency makes specific reference to the  publication Cloud Computing Security Risk Assessment, which plays an important role for the conclusions of the opinion about cloud risks. The opinion also makes a specific recommendation to use ’s Cloud Computing Information Assurance Framework.

Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control lists (ACLs) and access protected files.
 File and directory permissions are commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the appropriate permissions. File and directory ACL implementations vary by platform, but generally explicitly designate which users or groups can perform which actions (read, write, execute, etc.).
Most Linux and Linux-based platforms provide a standard set of permission groups (user, group, and other) and a standard set of permissions (read, write, and execute) that are applied to each group. While nuances of each platform’s permissions implementation may vary, most of the platforms provide two primary commands used to manipulate file and directory ACLs: 
 (short for change owner), and 
 (short for change mode).

New chair of the Article 19 Expert Group on security of e-Trust services
 is happy to announce that Ulrich Latzenhofer from RTR Austria will be the new chair of the Article 19 Expert Group which focuses on security of electronic trust services in the EU.

Electronic trust services is what we call services like digital signatures, digital certificates, electronic seals, timestamps, etc. used in electronic transactions, to make them secure, trustworthy. The eIDAS regulation, which came into force in 2016, provides the EU wide legal framework for both trust services and national eID schemes. Article 19 of the eIDAS regulation sets the security requirements for trust service providers. The Article 19 Expert Group was set up by  in 2015, under the auspices of the Commission, to support voluntary collaboration between Member States about the technical details of how to implement Article 19. This is a voluntary non-binding process, between experts from ministries, agencies, supervisory bodies, national authorities, et cetera, who are involved with the implementation of Article 19. The group has experts from EU member states as well as EEA and EFTA countries. The Article 19 Expert Group meets twice a year.
At the last meeting in October in Malta, hosted by the Maltese Communications Authority, the group agreed to a new terms of reference for the group, formalizing a new modus operandi. At this meeting a new chair was elected, Ulrich Latzenhofer from the Austrian Regulatory Authority for Broadcasting and Telecommunications, will chair the group for the next 2 years.  will continue to support the group in the role of secretariat.
For further information about this work see:
https://resilience..europa.eu/article-19 URL: https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/new-chair-of-the-article-19-expert-group-on-security-of-e-trust-services

CLIs are typically accessed locally, but can also be exposed via services, such as SSH, Telnet, and RDP.  Commands that are executed in the CLI execute with the current permissions level of the process running the terminal emulator, unless the command specifies a change in permissions context. Many controllers have CLI interfaces for management purposes.

CISA warns of exploitable Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 386/66 (IT) on Wednesday, August 23, 2023, reported that the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned organizations that a patched Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability from earlier this year, tracked as CVE-2023-26359, may be exploited in attacks. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog on Monday. Adobe addressed the vulnerability with its March 2023 Patch Tuesday updates, describing CVE-2023-26359 as a critical deserialization issue that can be exploited for arbitrary code execution. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to patch the vulnerability by September 11. Federal agencies are required to fix vulnerabilities added to the catalog under Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01 to mitigate risks posed by the flaws. CISA's KEV catalog currently lists 12 ColdFusion vulnerabilities, including four flaws discovered this year. While there is no information available at this time regarding attacks exploiting CVE-2023-26359, Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities can be exploited by various threat actors in their operations. The UK confirms that the Ministry of Defence was breached by the disclosure of payroll data.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Thursday, May 9, 2024, that the UK Government confirmed a threat actor had breached Ministry of Defence data, accessing parts of the military's payment network. The compromised system contained personal information of active and reserve personnel, including some retired veterans.  Defence Secretary Grant Shapps said the MoD was aware of the access and isolated the system to prevent the spread of the threat and stopped all payments. The incident did not affect salaries, pension payments to veterans.  The compromised system contained personal data, including names and bank details, and in some cases, the addresses of those affected.  The data belongs to approximately 272,000 military personnel and veterans. Currently, there is no evidence that hackers stole any other data. Those affected by the breach will be notified by letter about the incident and the information that may have been exposed.

Nuclei vulnerability risks signature bypass and malicious code execution

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 08/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 7, 2025.  A high-severity vulnerability (CVE-2024-43405) with a CVSS score of 7.4 has been identified in Nuclei, an open-source vulnerability scanner.  This vulnerability allows attackers to bypass signature verification and inject malicious code into templates.  The Wiz team reported that the vulnerability stems from differing newline character handling between signature verification and YAML parser data conversion, enabling attackers to insert malicious content while maintaining valid signatures in the normal section.

Nuclei supports various protocols, including HTTP, TCP, DNS, and Code, which can execute code on the operating system.  Using unsafe templates could lead to system compromise.  Wiz's report demonstrates that the "Code" protocol can be used to extract sensitive information from target systems if weaponized with malicious code.

This vulnerability affects Nuclei versions 3.0.0 and later and has been patched in version v3.3.2.  Users should verify templates before use to prevent malicious code injection.  Caution should be exercised when allowing users to modify or upload templates in shared systems to avoid the risk of attacks that could lead to unauthorized command execution, data theft, or system control.

 URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/07/%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88-nuclei-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b5%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%b9%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%88/

New animated logo of the European Cyber Security Month now online
The Agency is launching the animation of the European Cyber Security Month (ECMS) logo.

This
animated logo
has been achieved by using the portraits sent by people who participated in the
advertising campaign of 
, launched at the beginning of this summer, inviting them to become the ‘face’ of the ECSM. The animation underline the key features of the logo; the key symbolising security, the shape of a person in profile, and the human factor in the centre, among other
characteristics
.
The reasoning behind this campaign is to visualise that cyber security ultimately is backed up by people, showing their determination and commitment to do their part. This short animation will be used together with other material to promote cyber security to citizens.
The objectives of the European Cyber Security Month, which is taking place in October, is to increase knowledge of Network and Information Security (NIS) issues, modify perceptions of threats, and provide updated security information through education, good practices and competitions.

The European Commission’s Digital Agenda for Europe,
action point 32

Google abandons plan to phase out third-party cookies in Chrome
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 263/67 (IT) Wednesday, July 24, 2024. On Monday, Google announced the cancellation of its plan to phase out third-party cookies in the Chrome web browser, which began more than 4 years ago under the Privacy Sandbox project. This is in response to numerous privacy concerns. Anthony Chavez, Vice President at Google, said the company will launch a new experience in Chrome that allows users to choose to use cookies as needed and can change that option at any time.  Google is consulting with regulators and will collaborate with the industry in implementing this change.  Although browsers like Apple Safari and Mozilla Firefox have not supported third-party cookies since early 2020, Google continues to face difficulties in doing so due to its significant role in the online advertising market.  Efforts to balance privacy and ad support have met with intense scrutiny from regulators and privacy advocates.  This change comes just months after Google announced its plan to phase out third-party cookies again, which has been postponed several times due to concerns about fair competition in the digital advertising market. This cancellation reflects the challenge of getting industry consensus on a single solution for managing privacy on the internet. Sustained Activity by Threat Actors
The European Union Agency for Cybersecurity () and the CERT of the EU institutions, bodies and agencies (CERT-EU) jointly published a report to alert on sustained activity by particular threat actors. The malicious cyber activities of the presented threat actors pose a significant and ongoing threat to the European Union.

Recent operations pursued by these actors focused mainly on information theft, primarily via establishing persistent footholds within the network infrastructure of organisations of strategic relevance.
Decision makers and cybersecurity officers are the primary audiences of this joint publication.
 and CERT-EU strongly encourage all public and private sector organisations in the EU to apply the recommendations
listed in the current joint publication “Sustained Activity by specific Threat Actors.”
By applying these recommendations in a consistent and systematic manner,  and CERT-EU remain confident that organisations will reduce the risk of being compromised by the mentioned Advanced Persistent Threats, APTs, as well as substantially improve their cybersecurity posture and enhance the overall resilience against cyberattacks.
Download the Joint Publication
Background
In 2021, the EU Agency for Cybersecurity and CERT-EU signed an agreement on a structured cooperation to work together on capacity building, operational cooperation and knowledge and information sharing. The provision for a structured cooperation was included in the Cybersecurity Act of 2019.  and CERT-EU meet regularly to agree on joint activities to implement the Annual Cooperation Plans.

Neiman Marcus data breach disclosed after hackers offered to sell information. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 226/67 (IT) Wednesday, June 26, 2024. Neiman Marcus has disclosed a data breach affecting 64,000 people, as hackers announced the sale of customer data.  The investigation found that hackers gained access to personal information such as names, contact information, birthdays, and gift card numbers, but did not disclose gift card PINs. Neiman Marcus took control of the issue and immediately disabled access to the database, while also launching an investigation with cybersecurity experts and law enforcement. After the breach was revealed, a hacker using the name ‘Sp1d3r’ announced the sale of the Neiman Marcus database on a cybercrime forum, stating that they were demanding a ransom from the company, but the company refused to pay. The data was sold for $150,000 and claimed to contain information on over 180 million users, including information such as names, addresses, birthdays, email addresses, and some social security numbers. The campaign reportedly targeted customers who stored data on the Snowflake cloud, which is accessed by at least 165 organizations such as Ticketmaster, Santander Bank, Anheuser-Busch, Allstate, Advance Auto Parts, Mitsubishi, Progressive, and State Farm. Neiman Marcus confirmed to SecurityWeek that the incident was related to the Snowflake attack and is notifying the 64,000 affected customers, adding that the hacker's claims are exaggerated. Key Exchange without Entity Authentication # Description : 
The product performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
Performing a key exchange will preserve the integrity of the information sent between two entities, but this will not guarantee that the entities are who they claim they are. This may enable an attacker to impersonate an actor by modifying traffic between the two entities. Typically, this involves a victim client that contacts a malicious server that is impersonating a trusted server. If the client skips authentication or ignores an authentication failure, the malicious server may request authentication information from the user. The malicious server can then use this authentication information to log in to the trusted server using the victim's credentials, sniff traffic between the victim and trusted server, etc.

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Architecture and Design
Ensure that proper authentication is included in the system design.
Phase: Implementation
Understand and properly implement all checks necessary to ensure the identity of entities involved in encrypted communications.
 URL: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/322.html

The Philippines' Department of National Defense has ordered its personnel to stop using AI-powered image-generating applications.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 459/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 24, 2023.  The Philippines' Department of National Defense warned of the risks of using AI-powered applications to create images of individuals and ordered its personnel to immediately cease using such apps.  On October 14, Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro Jr. issued an order to stop using AI-powered image generation applications and to exercise caution in sharing information online.  This is due to the Philippine forces' ongoing efforts to quell decades-long communist and Muslim insurgencies, and to protect its interests in the disputed South China Sea.  It is currently unclear whether the order was issued in response to a specific incident or to address potential attacks aimed at exploiting data collected by these AI-powered applications. However, the memo warns about applications used to create digital avatar profile pictures after users submit at least 10 pictures of themselves. The avatars can then mimic how users actually speak and move.  The order states that these AI-powered applications pose significant privacy and security risks, as they can be misused to create fake profiles that can lead to identity theft, social engineering, phishing attacks, and other malicious activities. RHYSIDA ransomware group attacks Kuwait's Ministry of Finance.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 431/66 (IT) Thursday, September 28, 2023. Last week, a ransomware attack targeted the Kuwaiti government. The attack occurred on September 18th, and government experts immediately initiated incident response procedures to mitigate the cyber threat.  Kuwait's Ministry of Finance officially announced the incident on Twitter.  Officials shut down affected systems to prevent the threat from spreading. The Ministry's message indicated that payment and payroll systems were impacted, as they were hosted on a separate network. “The Ministry of Finance announces that one of its systems was subjected to a hacking attempt and the system was shut down.  Currently, the ministry is still unable to fully restore the system.” According to a press release issued by the Kuwaiti government this week, local authorities, including the National Cyber Center, are investigating the incident with assistance from cybersecurity companies. This week, the Rhysida ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack and added the ministry to the list of victims on its data leak site on the Tor network. The group also published a set of documents as proof of the hack. The Rhysida ransomware group has been operating since May 2023, according to the gang’s Tor leak site, and has listed at least 44 companies as victims of its attacks. Impair Defenses: Prevent Application Removal is techniques, 

Adversaries may abuse the Android device administration API to prevent the user from uninstalling a target application. In earlier versions of Android, device administrator applications needed their administration capabilities explicitly deactivated by the user before the application could be uninstalled. This was later updated so the user could deactivate and uninstall the administrator application in one step.
Adversaries may also abuse the device accessibility APIs to prevent removal. This set of APIs allows the application to perform certain actions on behalf of the user and programmatically determine what is being shown on the screen. The malicious application could monitor the device screen for certain modals (e.g., the confirmation modal to uninstall an application) and inject screen input or a back button tap to close the modal. For example, Android's 
 API could be utilized to prevent the user from removing the malicious application from the device after installation. If the user wants to uninstall the malicious application, two cases may occur, both preventing the user from removing the application.

Server Software Component: IIS Components is techniques, 

Adversaries may install malicious components that run on Internet Information Services (IIS) web servers to establish persistence. IIS provides several mechanisms to extend the functionality of the web servers. For example, Internet Server Application Programming Interface (ISAPI) extensions and filters can be installed to examine and/or modify incoming and outgoing IIS web requests. Extensions and filters are deployed as DLL files that export three functions: 
, 
, and (optionally) 
. IIS modules may also be installed to extend IIS web servers.
Adversaries may install malicious ISAPI extensions and filters to observe and/or modify traffic, execute commands on compromised machines, or proxy command and control traffic. ISAPI extensions and filters may have access to all IIS web requests and responses. For example, an adversary may abuse these mechanisms to modify HTTP responses in order to distribute malicious commands/content to previously comprised hosts.
Adversaries may also install malicious IIS modules to observe and/or modify traffic. IIS 7.0 introduced modules that provide the same unrestricted access to HTTP requests and responses as ISAPI extensions and filters. IIS modules can be written as a DLL that exports 
, or as a .NET application that interfaces with ASP.NET APIs to access IIS HTTP requests.

Masquerading: Space after Filename is techniques, 

Adversaries can hide a program's true filetype by changing the extension of a file. With certain file types (specifically this does not work with .app extensions), appending a space to the end of a filename will change how the file is processed by the operating system.
For example, if there is a Mach-O executable file called 
, when it is double clicked by a user, it will launch Terminal.app and execute. If this file is renamed to 
, then when double clicked by a user, it will launch with the default text editing application (not executing the binary). However, if the file is renamed to 
 (note the space at the end), then when double clicked by a user, the true file type is determined by the OS and handled appropriately and the binary will be executed 
.
Adversaries can use this feature to trick users into double clicking benign-looking files of any format and ultimately executing something malicious.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036/006/

Obfuscated Files or Information is techniques, 

Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit. This is common behavior that can be used across different platforms and the network to evade defenses. 
Payloads may be compressed, archived, or encrypted in order to avoid detection. These payloads may be used during Initial Access or later to mitigate detection. Sometimes a user's action may be required to open and 
 for 
. The user may also be required to input a password to open a password protected compressed/encrypted file that was provided by the adversary. 
 Adversaries may also use compressed or archived scripts, such as JavaScript. 
Portions of files can also be encoded to hide the plain-text strings that would otherwise help defenders with discovery. 
 Payloads may also be split into separate, seemingly benign files that only reveal malicious functionality when reassembled. 
Adversaries may also abuse 
 to obscure commands executed from payloads or directly via 
. Environment variables, aliases, characters, and other platform/language specific semantics can be used to evade signature based detections and application control mechanisms.

Browser Session Hijacking is techniques, 

Adversaries may take advantage of security vulnerabilities and inherent functionality in browser software to change content, modify user-behaviors, and intercept information as part of various browser session hijacking techniques.
A specific example is when an adversary injects software into a browser that allows them to inherit cookies, HTTP sessions, and SSL client certificates of a user then use the browser as a way to pivot into an authenticated intranet.
 Executing browser-based behaviors such as pivoting may require specific process permissions, such as 
 and/or high-integrity/administrator rights.
Another example involves pivoting browser traffic from the adversary's browser through the user's browser by setting up a proxy which will redirect web traffic. This does not alter the user's traffic in any way, and the proxy connection can be severed as soon as the browser is closed. The adversary assumes the security context of whichever browser process the proxy is injected into. Browsers typically create a new process for each tab that is opened and permissions and certificates are separated accordingly. With these permissions, an adversary could potentially browse to any resource on an intranet, such as 
 or webmail, that is accessible through the browser and which the browser has sufficient permissions. Browser pivoting may also bypass security provided by 2-factor authentication.

Cumbria Constabulary accidentally leaked officer data online.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/66 (IT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023: Cumbria Constabulary, a territorial police force in England, unintentionally published the names and salaries of all its officers and staff online.  This is the second UK agency in two weeks to admit to a data breach involving employee personal information. In this incident, Cumbria Police admitted that the names, salaries, and allowances of officers were indeed published on its website due to an unintentional human error.  The information was removed immediately after the accidental publication, but the police did not specify how long the data was online before the error was discovered. Cumbria Constabulary stated it had immediately contacted all affected officers to inform them of the minor impact and outline the measures being taken to manage the leak and prevent recurrence.  The incident was reported to the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO – the UK's data regulator), which reportedly stated that no further action was needed beyond advice and guidance. The ICO was reportedly satisfied with the Constabulary's actions and the stringent steps taken to prevent further data breaches. However, it is reported that Chief Constable Simon Byrne will be investigated by the watchdog and may face penalties. On Tuesday, Adobe released a large set of security patches for Acrobat Reader software, fixing at least 30 vulnerabilities affecting Windows and macOS installations. Modify Authentication Process: Password Filter DLL is techniques, 

Adversaries may register malicious password filter dynamic link libraries (DLLs) into the authentication process to acquire user credentials as they are validated. 
Windows password filters are password policy enforcement mechanisms for both domain and local accounts. Filters are implemented as DLLs containing a method to validate potential passwords against password policies. Filter DLLs can be positioned on local computers for local accounts and/or domain controllers for domain accounts. Before registering new passwords in the Security Accounts Manager (SAM), the Local Security Authority (LSA) requests validation from each registered filter. Any potential changes cannot take effect until every registered filter acknowledges validation. 
Adversaries can register malicious password filters to harvest credentials from local computers and/or entire domains. To perform proper validation, filters must receive plain-text credentials from the LSA. A malicious password filter would receive these plain-text credentials every time a password request is made.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1556/002/

Internet Archive Suffers Repeated Attack During System Recovery

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 22, 2024: The Internet Archive, a non-profit digital library, has been hit by another cyberattack during its recovery from a previous attack. This resulted in the exposure of user data for over 31 million users, including usernames, email addresses, and hashed passwords.  The attack also involved DDoS attacks and website defacement, causing most services, including the Wayback Machine, which archives billions of web pages, to be temporarily suspended.

Brewster Kahle, founder of the Internet Archive, revealed on Friday that some services, such as the Wayback Machine and Archive-It, are now back online and other services will be available soon. He confirmed that the archived data remains safe and that system restoration will be done carefully to strengthen cybersecurity defenses.

However, over the weekend, it was found that some users received additional security incident notification emails related to the Zendesk system used for customer service.  It was stated that the Internet Archive has not yet changed the exposed API key despite being aware of the issue for two weeks. Currently, the Internet Archive does not know who is behind the attacks. The BlackMeta group has claimed responsibility for the DDoS attack, but the system hacking appears to be the work of another, as yet unidentified, group.

How the operating system locates libraries to be used by a program can also be intercepted. Locations where the operating system looks for programs/resources, such as file directories and in the case of Windows the Registry, could also be poisoned to include malicious payloads.

The U.S. federal government has arrested two men involved in The Warzone RAT operation.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 60/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 13, 2024.  The Department of Justice announced the seizure of domains used to sell the Warzone RAT Trojan for remote access.  The seizure is the result of an international law enforcement operation. Federal authorities in Boston seized www.warzone[.]ws and three related domains that sold Warzone RAT malware, a remote access trojan (RAT) that allows cybercriminals to connect to victims' computers for malicious purposes, such as browsing the victim's file system, taking screenshots, logging keystrokes, stealing usernames and passwords, and viewing the victim through their camera, all without the victim's knowledge or consent.  The U.S. investigation led to charges against two men: Daniel Meli (27) and Prince Onyeoziri Odinakachi (31).  Both were charged with selling and supporting Warzone RAT and other malware.  The two were arrested on February 7, 2024, on charges of conspiracy, accessing a protected computer to obtain information, and illegally selling and advertising interception devices.  Each faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. workshop on IoT Security for Smart Home environments
N/A

On October 6
th
2015,  organised a workshop to validate its study on IoT (internet of things) security for smart home environments in Berlin. The workshop gathered over twenty participants with various backgrounds including product manufacturers, solution vendors, developers, academia and researchers, CERTs, and policy makers.
 presented its project and good security practices to secure IoT in smart home environments. The Agency’s work has been validated based on participants’ input, and will be contributing further in the field by providing guidance.
Participants also presented their work in the IoT security domain. This included:
EU policy and research aspects (Dr Thibaut Kleiner, European Commission, DG CONNECT)
firmware security (Dr Andrei Costin, Eurecom / Firmware.RE)
IoT security and privacy framework (Mr Craig Spiezle, OTAlliance.org)
CERT for IoT (Mr Cédric Messeguer,Digital Security and Mr.Thomas Gayet, CERT UBIK).
Key conclusions, in consensus, show:
IoT security is needed during the whole lifecycle of devices and services (starting at the early stages of a project, for their implementation and up to their end of life).
Collaboration of all stakeholders is required to harmonise the definition of security for IoT
Awareness raising is important, both for decision-makers and end-users
Workshop presentations are now available on the event page:
 Workshop on Cyber security for IoT in Smart Home Environments.
October is Cyber Security Month! Follow #CyberSecMonth #

[TLP:GREEN] Alert - Additional Investigation Report on Attacks in the BangkokShell Campaign

The TTC-CERT has investigated several suspicious files received from a security agency in Thailand and found that all files are related to the BangkokShell cyber attack campaign.  TTC-CERT previously published information about this campaign in June 2023 in a report titled "Alert - Report on the Discovery of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand" (https://drive.google.com/file/d/14OdsocsRVK6osG3TLxyGSB0fJZaaS2fK/view).  The results of this analysis indicate that the malware files were compiled before the malware files found in the report "Alert - Report on the Discovery of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand." However, there are differences in Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs), which indicate that the attackers' operations have been ongoing and that they are continuously improving and developing their malware and seeking tools to achieve their objectives. This report will describe the overall functionality of the malware files found, analyze the changes that have occurred, and understand the reasons behind these changes.

TTC-CERT has prepared this alert report and identified "Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)" to inform organizations and the general public. This information can be used to assess risks and take appropriate actions to secure information systems and networks.  If your organization is connected to the TTC-CERT MISP system, the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) from this report will be sent to your MISP instance.

Domain or Tenant Policy Modification is techniques, 

Adversaries may modify the configuration settings of a domain or identity tenant to evade defenses and/or escalate privileges in centrally managed environments. Such services provide a centralized means of managing identity resources such as devices and accounts, and often include configuration settings that may apply between domains or tenants such as trust relationships, identity syncing, or identity federation.
Modifications to domain or tenant settings may include altering domain Group Policy Objects (GPOs) in Microsoft Active Directory (AD) or changing trust settings for domains, including federation trusts relationships between domains or tenants.
With sufficient permissions, adversaries can modify domain or tenant policy settings. Since configuration settings for these services apply to a large number of identity resources, there are a great number of potential attacks malicious outcomes that can stem from this abuse. Examples of such abuse include:  
Adversaries may temporarily modify domain or tenant policy, carry out a malicious action(s), and then revert the change to remove suspicious indicators.

OpenSSL has released patches for 2 high-severity vulnerabilities. Users should update immediately.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reports OpenSSL, an open-source library used for encrypting data via SSL and TLS protocols (used by various software such as Linux operating systems, web servers, chat programs, and VPN connection programs), released patches on March 25, 2021, addressing two high-severity vulnerabilities affecting versions 1.1.1 and later.  Users are advised to update to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The first vulnerability, CVE-2021-3449, is a Denial of Service (DoS) vulnerability, allowing attackers to send malicious messages from a client machine to target OpenSSL servers, potentially disrupting service. The second, CVE-2021-3450, is an Improper Certificate Authority vulnerability, leading to certificate validation errors.  Exploit code for CVE-2021-3449 has been reported.  To avoid potential risks, users of OpenSSL version 1.1.1 and later should update to version 1.1.1k immediately.

Cybercriminals accelerate online scams during Ramadan. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 118/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Resecurity has observed a significant increase in fraud and scam activity during Ramadan in the Middle East. Organizations in the Middle East face increased fraud risks, especially in Saudi Arabia, where consumer spending ranks highest in the region, exceeding $16 billion. This surge is driven by rapidly increasing e-commerce activity, which has attracted cybercriminals seeking to exploit platforms for scams, resulting in significant financial impacts for both consumers and businesses.  The overall financial impact is estimated between $70 and $100 million. Resecurity has protected its clients by blocking over 320 fraud and scam attempts impersonating logistics providers and e-government services. Cybercriminals exploit platforms like Sadad, Musaned, Ajeer, Ejar, and well-known logistics services to trick internet users into various scams. Resecurity advises clients not to disclose personal and payment information on suspicious websites or to individuals impersonating bank or government employees. Microsoft Patch Tuesday for March 2024 addressed 59 vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 102/67 (IT) Thursday, March 14, 2024, Microsoft released the March 2023 Patch Tuesday update that addressed 59 vulnerabilities in its products. Two vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-21407 and CVE-2024-21408, are rated Critical, and the remaining 57 are rated Important.

- CVE-2024-21407 is a Remote Code Execution vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.
- CVE-2024-21408 is a Denial of Service vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.

The most severe vulnerability addressed by Microsoft is an Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) Remote Code Execution vulnerability, CVE-2024-21334 (CVSS 9.8). An unauthenticated attacker could execute code on OMI instances accessible over the internet. Currently, none of the vulnerabilities addressed in the March 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday security update have been exploited in attacks.

The full list of vulnerabilities Microsoft patched in March 2024 can be found at https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/blog/2024/3/12/the-march-2024-security-update-review

Freecycle website confirms data breach affecting 7 million users.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 403/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 6, 2023.  The Freecycle website, an online community created by people who want to reduce waste and recycle unnecessary items, is a place where members can exchange information about unwanted items and arrange for pick-up and delivery.  Freecycle, a non-profit organization, has confirmed a large-scale data breach affecting more than 7 million users. The data breach was discovered a few weeks after stolen data was offered for sale on a data trading website on May 30th.  The stolen data includes usernames, user IDs, email addresses, and MD5-hashed passwords. According to Freecycle's report, no other information was disclosed. After learning of the breach, Freecycle said it reported the incident to relevant authorities and warned affected users to immediately change their account passwords. They also advised users to be wary of phishing emails and to avoid clicking on links in emails from unknown sources. Lumen blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon from its network after discovering they were targeting attacks in the US and globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 04/67 (IT) on Friday, January 3, 2025, reported that Lumen successfully blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon, linked to China, from its network.  They confirmed that no customer data was accessed or leaked.  Salt Typhoon, also known as FamousSparrow and GhostEmperor, has been active since 2019, targeting government agencies and telecommunications companies worldwide.  Recently, they infiltrated nine US telecommunications companies as part of a cyber espionage campaign.  Anne Neuberger, the White House cybersecurity advisor, revealed that the attacks focused on Americans' metadata, including communications of key figures in government and politics.  In early December 2024, it was reported that Salt Typhoon had penetrated telecommunications companies in dozens of countries. The Wall Street Journal further reported that at least eight US telecommunications companies were previously affected.  In addition to Lumen, major providers such as AT&T and Verizon confirmed they successfully strengthened network security and prevented attacks.  Meanwhile, T-Mobile stated that the hackers attempted to penetrate their systems but were unable to access sensitive data or company systems. This incident highlights the importance of cybersecurity measures in the telecommunications sector, which plays a crucial role in national security. Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling is techniques, 

Adversaries may smuggle data and files past content filters by hiding malicious payloads inside of seemingly benign HTML files. HTML documents can store large binary objects known as JavaScript Blobs (immutable data that represents raw bytes) that can later be constructed into file-like objects. Data may also be stored in Data URLs, which enable embedding media type or MIME files inline of HTML documents. HTML5 also introduced a download attribute that may be used to initiate file downloads.
Adversaries may deliver payloads to victims that bypass security controls through HTML Smuggling by abusing JavaScript Blobs and/or HTML5 download attributes. Security controls such as web content filters may not identify smuggled malicious files inside of HTML/JS files, as the content may be based on typically benign MIME types such as 
 and/or 
. Malicious files or data can be obfuscated and hidden inside of HTML files through Data URLs and/or JavaScript Blobs and can be deobfuscated when they reach the victim (i.e. 
), potentially bypassing content filters.
For example, JavaScript Blobs can be abused to dynamically generate malicious files in the victim machine and may be dropped to disk by abusing JavaScript functions such as 
.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/006/

Web Service is techniques, 

Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for relaying data to/from a compromised system. Popular websites, cloud services, and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google, Microsoft, or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise.
 Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
Use of Web services may also protect back-end C2 infrastructure from discovery through malware binary analysis while also enabling operational resiliency (since this infrastructure may be dynamically changed).
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102

Clop Ransomware group steals data from major hospitals in North Carolina
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 420/66 (IT) Tuesday, September 19, 2023. Nuance, a Microsoft-owned technology company, has revealed that the Clop Ransomware group has stolen personal data from major hospitals in North Carolina as part of the Progress MOVEit Transfer campaign. MOVEit Transfer is used for secure file transfers using SFTP, SCP, and HTTP uploads. The Clop Ransomware group (also known as Lace Tempest) has been credited by Microsoft for the campaign that exploited the Zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-34362 in the MOVEit Transfer platform. The company said the Clop group may have stolen personal data from several hospitals in North Carolina and other healthcare providers, including: – Atrium Health – Catawba Valley Medical Center – Charlotte Radiology – Duke University Health System – DLP Central Carolina Medical Center – ECU Health – FirstHealth of the Carolinas – Mission Health System – Novant Health – Novant Health New Hanover Regional Medical Center – UNC Health – Wake Radiology Diagnostic Imaging – WakeMed Health and Hospitals. Currently, many hospitals in the United States have been targeted by cyberattacks. The Rhysida Ransomware group has added three more U.S. hospitals to the list of victims on its Tor site after the PROSPECT MEDICAL attack on the systems of 3 hospitals and other healthcare facilities. Locations where the operating system looks for programs or resources, such as file directories, could also be poisoned to include malicious payloads.

ED Udo Helmbrecht at the Digital Enlightenment Forum 2013
Today (19th September), 's Executive Director, Professor Udo Helmbrecht, took part in the Digital Enlightenment Forum 2013.

Professor Hembrecht presented 's work on Trustworthy Infrastructure for Personal Data Management. The key points of his presentation were:
The Right to be Forgotten:  addressed the technical means of assisting the enforcement of the right to be forgotten.
Notification about security breaches in EU legislation: Notification schemes are crucial for transparency and awareness about the risks of processing personal data in online systems.
Standardisation: The current approach towards standards in the EU needs vision for the future.
The Digital Enlightenment Forum 2013 took place from 18-19 September in Brussels. This year's discussions were focused on
personal data and citizenship in the digital society. Key speakers included Sir Tim Berners-Lee (Director World Wide Web Consortium), Robert Madelin (Director General CNECT, EC) and Peter Hustinx (European Data Protection Supervisor).

Clorox Company, a manufacturer of cleaning products, has partially shut down systems after a cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 380/66 (IT) Friday, August 18, 2023, The Clorox Company has been the victim of a cyber incident and has partially shut down systems in response to the cyber attack.  Clorox Company is a multinational consumer goods company specializing in the manufacture and marketing of household cleaning products. In response to the attack, the company has taken some systems offline while increasing security precautions. Clorox has notified law enforcement and engaged leading cybersecurity experts to investigate and determine the scope of the incident.  It is not yet clear whether the attackers stole company data. In addition, the company announced it will implement temporary workarounds, including offline operations, to continue serving customers.  The company has not yet disclosed the details of the attack, but its response to the incident suggests it may have been the victim of a ransomware attack.

Indicator Removal: Clear Command History is techniques, 

In addition to clearing system logs, an adversary may clear the command history of a compromised account to conceal the actions undertaken during an intrusion. Various command interpreters keep track of the commands users type in their terminal so that users can retrace what they've done.
On Linux and macOS, these command histories can be accessed in a few different ways. While logged in, this command history is tracked in a file pointed to by the environment variable 
. When a user logs off a system, this information is flushed to a file in the user's home directory called 
. The benefit of this is that it allows users to go back to commands they've used before in different sessions.
Adversaries may delete their commands from these logs by manually clearing the history (
) or deleting the bash history file 
.  
Adversaries may also leverage a 
 on network devices to clear command history data (
 and/or 
).
On Windows hosts, PowerShell has two different command history providers: the built-in history and the command history managed by the 
 module. The built-in history only tracks the commands used in the current session. This command history is not available to other sessions and is deleted when the session ends.
The 
 command history tracks the commands used in all PowerShell sessions and writes them to a file (
 by default). This history file is available to all sessions and contains all past history since the file is not deleted when the session ends.
Adversaries may run the PowerShell command 
 to flush the entire command history from a current PowerShell session. This, however, will not delete/flush the 
 file. Adversaries may also delete the 
 file or edit its contents to hide PowerShell commands they have run.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1070/003/

Activate Firmware Update Mode is techniques, 

Adversaries may activate firmware update mode on devices to prevent expected response functions from engaging in reaction to an emergency or process malfunction. For example, devices such as protection relays may have an operation mode designed for firmware installation. This mode may halt process monitoring and related functions to allow new firmware to be loaded. A device left in update mode may be placed in an inactive holding state if no firmware is provided to it. By entering and leaving a device in this mode, the adversary may deny its usual functionalities.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T0800

Threat Actor is selling 30 million customer records allegedly stolen from TEG.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 225/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 25, 2024.  A Threat Actor is offering for sale customer data allegedly stolen from the Australian ticketing company TEG. TEG (Ticketek Entertainment Group) is an Australian company operating in the live entertainment and ticketing industry. The company operates in several countries and sells more than 30 million tickets annually for more than 30,000 events, including live sports, concerts, theater performances, festivals, and exhibitions.  TechCrunch reported that a Threat Actor was found offering stolen customer data from TEG on a popular forum. The Threat Actor claims to have data from over 30 million users, such as names, usernames, gender, birthdays, passwords, and email addresses. They shared some sample data as proof.

In May, Ticketek disclosed a cyberattack affecting Ticketek Australia user account data. This data was stored on a cloud platform, and although Ticketek did not disclose the provider's name, experts believe it may be Snowflake. The Snowflake data breach affected 165 customers, including Ticketmaster, Santander Bank, and possibly Cylance. TechCrunch is verifying some of the data, but Snowflake has not yet commented on the TEG data breach.

Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication # Description : 
The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
Since an implicit intent does not specify a particular application to receive the data, any application can process the intent by using an Intent Filter for that intent. This can allow untrusted applications to obtain sensitive data. There are two variations on the standard broadcast intent, ordered and sticky.
Ordered broadcast intents are delivered to a series of registered receivers in order of priority as declared by the Receivers. A malicious receiver can give itself a high priority and cause a denial of service by stopping the broadcast from propagating further down the chain. There is also the possibility of malicious data modification, as a receiver may also alter the data within the Intent before passing it on to the next receiver. The downstream components have no way of asserting that the data has not been altered earlier in the chain.
Sticky broadcast intents remain accessible after the initial broadcast. An old sticky intent will be broadcast again to any new receivers that register for it in the future, greatly increasing the chances of information exposure over time. Also, sticky broadcasts cannot be protected by permissions that may apply to other kinds of intents.
In addition, any broadcast intent may include a URI that references data that the receiving component does not normally have the privileges to access. The sender of the intent can include special privileges that grant the receiver read or write access to the specific URI included in the intent. A malicious receiver that intercepts this intent will also gain those privileges and be able to read or write the resource at the specified URI.

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Implementation
If the application only requires communication with its own components, then the destination is always known, and an explicit intent could be used.

Canada orders TikTok to shut down operations in Canada due to security concerns.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/67 (IT) for Friday, November 8, 2024.  The Canadian government has ordered TikTok, owned by ByteDance in China, to cease operations in the country.  The decision is stated to be the result of a national security risk assessment.  The review was conducted by Canada’s security and intelligence community. The government emphasized that it will not restrict access to TikTok for the general Canadian public, but advised citizens to assess the potential risks of using the social media app.  François-Philippe Champagne, Canada’s Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry, stated that the government wants citizens to be aware of the risks of using social media platforms, particularly in terms of data management and security related to foreign countries. TikTok has been banned on government devices since February 2023.  TikTok responded that closing the office in Canada will result in hundreds of employees being laid off.  The company intends to challenge this order in court.  In a statement, ByteDance confirmed that no user data will be shared with the Chinese government. However, concerns remain that TikTok may be forced to hand over user data. This has resulted in the U.S. enacting a law requiring ByteDance to sell TikTok by January 2025 or face a ban in the country. Currently, TikTok is completely banned in several countries, including Afghanistan, India, Nepal, and Pakistan, and is prohibited on government-issued devices in many countries around the world. Attacks against information systems - good practice collection for CERTs
N/A

Today  publishes its Good Practice Collection for CERTs on the
EU Directive on attacks against information systems
.  It was produced to support the efficient functioning of CERTs/CSIRTs and their cooperation with law enforcement agencies (LEAs) in the face of a new development in European cybercrime policy.
's new report serves two major goals, which both aim at supporting CERTs/CSIRTs:
Firstly to provide an analysis of the legal framework created by the Directive, coupled with a stock taking on relevant existing national activities and good practices;
Secondly, the identification of key areas and, where appropriate, guidelines and recommendations derived from these good practices
For the full report:
A Good Practice Collection for CERTs on the Directive on attacks against information systems
Background:
In 2010, the European Commission published a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on attacks against information systems . This proposal was intended to further streamline the legal framework in the Member States in relation to the definition and punishment of certain cybercrime incidents, and tackled several challenges which were not adequately dealt with under prior rules, such as notably the creation, use and dissemination of cybercrime tools, the penalisation of illegal interception, the use of botnets, and identity theft.
The proposal was adopted by the European Parliament on 22 July 2013 and published in the Official Journal on 14 August 2013 as Directive 2013/40/EU. The Directive, which Member States will need to transpose by 4 September 2015, imposes new obligations, tasks and expectations on certain key stakeholders, including CERTs/CSIRTs, LEAs, security specialists, telecommunications service providers, etc. URL: https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/attacks-against-information-systems-good-practice-collection-for-certs

Rogue Master is techniques, 

Adversaries may setup a rogue master to leverage control server functions to communicate with outstations. A rogue master can be used to send legitimate control messages to other control system devices, affecting processes in unintended ways. It may also be used to disrupt network communications by capturing and receiving the network traffic meant for the actual master. Impersonating a master may also allow an adversary to avoid detection. 
In the case of the 2017 Dallas Siren incident, adversaries used a rogue master to send command messages to the 156 distributed sirens across the city, either through a single rogue transmitter with a strong signal, or using many distributed repeaters.

Cencora, a pharmaceutical giant, has been hit by a cyberattack, with data stolen from its IT systems. Cencora, formerly known as AmerisourceBergen, provides pharmaceutical services, distributing medicines and solutions for medical offices, pharmacies, and animal health. On February 21, 2024, Cencora discovered that its data had been stolen, some of which may include personal information.  The company filed an 8-K form with the SEC. Currently, there is no additional information on which attackers or ransomware are claiming responsibility for the attack. External Remote Services is techniques, 

Adversaries may leverage external remote services as a point of initial access into your network. These services allow users to connect to internal network resources from external locations. Examples are VPNs, Citrix, and other access mechanisms. Remote service gateways often manage connections and credential authentication for these services. 
External remote services allow administration of a control system from outside the system. Often, vendors and internal engineering groups have access to external remote services to control system networks via the corporate network. In some cases, this access is enabled directly from the internet. While remote access enables ease of maintenance when a control system is in a remote area, compromise of remote access solutions is a liability. The adversary may use these services to gain access to and execute attacks against a control system network. Access to valid accounts is often a requirement. 
As they look for an entry point into the control system network, adversaries may begin searching for existing point-to-point VPN implementations at trusted third party networks or through remote support employee connections where split tunneling is enabled.

D-Link confirms Data Breach, employee falls victim to Phishing attack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 456/66 (IT) Thursday, October 19, 2023. Taiwanese network equipment manufacturer D-Link confirms a data breach that exposed low-sensitivity and semi-public information. The company confirms that the data is not from the cloud system, but is expected to be from the old D-View system, which reached end-of-life in early 2015. The data was used for registration purposes. So far, there is no evidence that the old data contains user IDs or financial information. A post shared on BreachForums on October 1, 2023, revealed the theft of personal information of a large number of government officials in Taiwan, including source code for D-Link's D-View network management software. D-Link has contacted cybersecurity firm Trend Micro to investigate the incident. In addition, there was an incident where an employee fell victim to a Phishing attack, and the company has increased operational security.  The exact details of the attack have not yet been released, but the company emphasizes that current customers may not be affected by this incident.
